editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE Rambling Justice, OR THE JEALOUS HUSBANDS.
With the Humours of Sir John Twiford. As it is acted at the THEATRE ROYAL.
LONDON, Printed by E. F. for Thomas Orrell and Iames Vade, at the Hand and Scepter, and Cock and Sugar-Loafe, near St. Dunstan's Church, in Fleetstreet. 1678.

div.head: PROLOGUE, spoken by Flora.
div.l: WILL nothing take in these Ill-natur'd times?
Neither low Farce nor great Heroick Rhimes?
'Tis strange you should such Sectaries be grown,
Thus to allow no Doctrine but your Own;
And in the Pit as they in Pulpits rage,
Preach up Rebellion to undoe the Stage.
Like angry Fate you Damn without Controul,
Ruine your Own, but not the Poets Soul.
If Wit should be the Substance of a Spark,
Why is your Talk so Dull? your Sence so Dark?
Things much admir'd by Fops both great and small,
Are to be Drunk, keep Miss, and visit Ball;
But the great Essence, Wit, few have at all.
Wit does in Plays to some Gay Fops appear,
Like a New Mistress in their full Carear;
All Ayre and Charming, till the Minute's past,
And then you kick her out with all your hast,
Tax'd with the Crime, Damme she's False you cry,
Another Lord keeps her as well as I.
This makes the Trade of Miss and Poet Dull,
They care not how Debauch'd to please a Fool.
But what's all this to me? I've yet been true,
But 'twas for want of Wit, like some of you.
'Sdeath who would be so singularly kind,
Toblige but One? Faith they' re not of my mind.
'Tis Wit in Women to accept of All,
The Knight, the Squire, but Gold in Generall.
The more they swarm, the greater store comes in,
And 'twill be pleasure then to pay for Sin.
But to be left in this unruly sort
By you the Great Pretenders of the Court,
Would make a Saint, a Mistress ne're so true,
Forget her Vows, and prove as False as you;
Turning her House, since you are grown so Fickle,
As we must ours, into a Conventicle.
There's no Redemption, thank our daily Iars,
The Men are all resolv'd go to Wars;
The Women thus grown out of Favour too,
Must in Remotes begin and trade a new.
Then if you chance to have the least Desire,
And come though overchang'd with Love and Fire,
Perhaps wee'l take your Guinnies and Retire.
Cheat you as n • w with a Dull Lenten Play,
And being Stock'd and Brisk sneak quite away.
Laugh at these Huffing Criticks of the Pit,
Who come in Droves to seize this Monster Wit.

row.cell: A Gentleman of a free Nature, a Generall Lover.
A Country Justice, fond of all Women.
A Gentleman of no Fortune, sometimes Lunatick.
Captain of the Gipsies, and other Gipsies Men and Women.
Daughters to Sir Arthur by a former Wife.

div.head: THE RAMBLING JUSTICE, OR THE Jealous Husbands.
ACT the First.
SCENE London.
div.stage: Enter as in discourse Arthur and Spywell.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: URGE me no more, I like it not.

sp.speaker: Spyw.
sp.p: Take Reason with you Sir, and let that guide your Passion; Sir Amorous is too much a Gentleman to injure you i'th' least, he is all Ayre, all Freeness, all Conversation.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Yes, and all Love too, that I have heard and fear; I like his all Ayre, all Freeness and all Conversation very well, but I hate his all Love. Sir, I must beg your Masters pardon, my house has no room for such all Loving Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Spyw.
sp.p: Then he is all Generosity, all Honour, and parts with his Money, Plate and Jewells.—

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Ha! what said you there? is he all Money too?

sp.speaker: Spyw.
sp.p: Made up with Gold and Silver, and values it as lightly.—

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p:
Ha! does he so? let him come in, I love a Gentleman that is all Money with my Heart, I do indeed. Exit Spyw.
I smell, I smell a Design, but let him work on, I have two pair of Eyes, and can as soon discover the Intrigues of love, as the Youngest Hector of 'em all, he hath Money, and he hath Writings for Land, two Excellent properties to come under an Aldermans Roof. Bramble.

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p:
Bid your Mistriss, 'las what did I say, bid your Lady keep her Chamber, let her not come so much as to the Window, upon her Perill and yours; for if I spy her though Ten score Yards distance from my new Lodger, I'le put you into the Bryers, look to't d'ye hear. [Ex. Bramble.
Enter Sir Generall and Spywell. Sir Generall Amorous, your Servant, Methinks I hunger and thirst to doe you service, you were to blame, indeed you were, not to make use of my poor House before.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: I am happy in having so great a Blessing laid upon me, to be under the Roof of such a worthy Friend.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: You are pleas'd to Complement, I know you are, I could have done it once too, but that time is past, my dancing Dayes are done.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Yet you are Fresh and Gay Sir as the Morning, and have the same Desires you had in Youth: but where's your Wife? Methinks I long to see my Charming Landlady.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Pox on him, does he begin so soon? he has scarce breath'd since he came in, and ask for her already; [Aside. Alas Sir, my Wife is gone to take the Ayre, She and my Girles just now took Coach together.

sp.speaker: Spyw.
sp.p: As we were coming in I saw her in her Balcone.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: A Rogue Bramble,—'Sounds in a Balcone. [Aside. You are mistaken Sir, indeed you are, she went to Epsom yesterday.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, nay now I find you jeast, come, come Sir you are a merry man, and I know Love to be jocost: what say you shall I see Eudoria?

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Not in her time of sickness, she never permits any man to visit her then, Sir, she has such strange fits, a kind of idle Frenzy.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: I long to see her then, for nothing in the world can more delight me than to see Beauty in as fit of madness, oh how they Charm! but is she often troubled?

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Once a Month, and then she looks so strangely.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: 'Las poor Soul, I fain would trespass Sir upon your Goodness, but the arguments you give me are so many I dare not plead against 'em.

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: Sir, Sir.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: The News with you?

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: My Lady Eudoria, and your Daughter Emilia are in such a fit of Laughter, that unless you come in to her assistance, and turn the source of their prodigious Mirth, I fear 'twill overcome 'em.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: My Wife Laughing? out you lying Varlet.

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: As I hope to be sav'd I saw her Sir, she laugh'd extreamly.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Peace Hell-hound or—Pox of the babling [Aside. Dog, all's spoil'd now—Alas Sir Amorous, my Man is Frantick, as mad as a March Hare: my Wife Laughing? she is the most melancholy Creature in Europe, she never Smiles nor Laughs, unless at Prayers, or at Church.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Be not so angry Sir, he might mistake.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: A Pox of his Mistakes, I hate 'em Sir.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Come hither Bramble,—is thy Mistress sick?

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: O law Sir.—

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Nay tell me, Sir Arthur shall be pleas'd, how does thy Lady?

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: Well Sir, well.—

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p:
Is she so Rascall?[Strikes Bramble. Pardon me Sir Amorous. A man may have leave to jeast with his Friend, intruth he may, she is within, indeed she is, I did not intend to hinder her your Company, only to raise your Expectations to a pitch. Call in your Mistress, Rascall. Now shall I be made a Cuckold before my face, [Ex. Bramble. I know I shall, if I prevent it not— [Aside.] I believe Mr. Amorous you take me for a Jealous man, a very Jealous fool I'le warrant
you, such another as Contentious Surly is. But i'faith you are mistaken, for my Pigsny is too Virtuous to have the least mistrust upon her, she is indeed.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: I must confess Contentious Surly Rules more like a Madman than a Husband, and looks upon his Wife not with the Eyes of Reason but of Rage, who is all Innocence and Goodness, and I dare swear would not wrong her Husband.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Not for a World, I know she would not. Alas poor Lady, this it is to have Chastity and Goodness lodg'd under a Jealous Roof, I thank my Stars I am free from it.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p:
You are the Happier Man, Sir Arthur.
Enter Eudoria, Emilia and Bramble. But yonder comes the Comfort of my Soul, who like a Glittering Star points all its Beams this way, whilst I the only Wretched of Mankind, dare but admire and gaze.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Sir Amorous be Complaisant, I prethee be, I am not Jealous, fack I am not, what! look upon a Lady and not dare salute her?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Indeed I dare not, my Oath has bound me from so great a Blessing.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Nay if you have Sworn, I have done.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: However to oblige so good a Friend I will be perjur'd once. [Goes to Eudoria. Madam I hope my strangeness will not appear Rude or Unmannerly, for in your Eyes I read a Happy Fate, and Glorious Blessings wait on every smile, but when they're Check'd by the malign Aspect of such a dogged Planet, I must only with this Retire.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: 'Tis my Ill fortune Sir, to live a Stranger from the Blest society of man, and only Eat, and Drink and Sleep with an all-seeing Argus, who is—I know not what.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: I can but pity for a time, then strive to get your Freedome.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Why that's well said, to her again Boy, to her again. Intruth she hath as good a—Hand as any she in Europe.

sp.speaker: Twif.
sp.p:
Good Morrow Cousin Arthur, and you Cousin Eudoria, and you Cousin Emilia. I protest my Lady Cousins at
Court are extreamly Well, Extraordinarily Jocost and Pleasant, and my Lord had the Mighty Fortune just now to win a hundred Guinnies of the Earle my Cousin, and how fares my Lord Amorous? What, Dogged?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: No Mr. Twiford, so far from that, I ne're was better pleas'd.

sp.speaker: Twif.
sp.p: I'le tell you my Lord th' effects of this day's Hunting. The Duke my Uncle, and my Lord my Extraordinary good Friend and Cousin, would needs take me in their Coach to go a Hunting.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: How! in their Coach Mr. Twiford?

sp.speaker: Twif.
sp.p: Yes, in their Coach Cousin Arthur. Alas 'tis the fashion now, all a Mode indeed; and being come to Hide Park, we unbrac'd the Horses, put our Hats underneath for Saddles, and run the four mile Course so pleasantly: but by my Honour I beat 'em a whole Coach length, Poal and all.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: I do believe you. Mr. Amorous my new Friend and Lodger, welcome once more, come let's retire, the Morning Ayr is bleak.

sp.speaker: Twyf.
sp.p: It is indeed, my Cousin Arthur advises well, and truly I am something weary, for I just now came from Hampton Court. And upon my word my Cousin is very well, and all the rest of the Lords and Ladies at Court, they are indeed.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: I am glad to hear it, come Sir Generall.

sp.speaker: Twif.
sp.p: Indeed Cousin you are very obliging, nay without Ceremony my Lord.

sp.speaker: Spyw.
sp.p: Hark. How long have you lived here?

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: Too long by a fortnight, sixteen days.

sp.speaker: Spyw.
sp.p: What, and weary of thy Service already?

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: The Devil cannot live Contentedly under my Masters Roof, we are all Prisoners, and he the head Jaylour. Sometimes but very seldome I have the Keeping of my Lady.

sp.speaker: Spyw.
sp.p: What, under Lock and Key?

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: Yes, and Bolts, and Barrs too; he is as Jealous as he is Old, as Old as he is Crafty, and as Crafty as the Devil. Nothing can Cozen him.

sp.speaker: Spyw.
sp.p: Nor Cuckold him neither?

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: I believe not, for all my Lady has a mind to it. She smil'd upon me the other day, and the Jealous Coxcomb brake my Head for't.

sp.speaker: Spyw.
sp.p: 'Twas ill done indeed. Here, canst thou be secret?

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: As a Churchwarden, let all the poors Money slip into my Pocket, and not declare it.

sp.speaker: Spyw.
sp.p: You are fit for my Masters turn then: know, that Sir Generall Amorous was sent hither by Contentious Surley to Cuckold your Master, but he knowing no design could be brought about without the help of some Servant or other in the house, ordered me to make Choice of one, whom I should think Convenient.

sp.speaker: Bram.
sp.p: I shall be glad to serve you Sir.

sp.speaker: Spyw.
sp.p: I am not Unsensible your Lady every Afternoon walks into the Garden, where over the purling Fountain she mourns for the Loss she sustains in having only the Ruins of a Man.

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: True Sir.

sp.speaker: Spyw.
sp.p: She being entered, I would have you oblige me with the Key of the Garden Gate, that my Master may go in and out at pleasure.

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: It shall be done Sir.

sp.speaker: Spyw.
sp.p: That's all at present, but fail not.

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: I will not Sir, I will not. This shall to my Master, perhaps he will reward me nobly for saving his honour, and keeping his Horns from Budding.

sp.speaker: Spyw.
sp.p: With this first Plot I'll try the hasty Servant, which if he spoil I value not, for nothing shall be acted I have told him, but every Wheel move in another Frame. I've help'd Contentious to his Horns already, and it shall be hard if Twilight scape my Policy.

div.stage: Enter Contentious Surly and Petulant Easy.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: What have I done to merit your Disgrace!

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: Enough.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: Have I in ought transgress'd the Laws of Wedlock?

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: With whom?

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: One whom I to day remov'd, Sir Generall Amorous, have I not seen him gaze upon your Face, bask in the Sunshine of your Early favours, whilst you as wantonly as common Sinners exchang'd both Smiles and Glances?

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: Can you blame her for Civill Courtesies, who smiles upon a man that brings you profit, heaps up those Coffers which before were empty, and all if I but smile?

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: By Heav'n th' Ambassador for greater Sins, him and his profits I've remov'd from hence, and will do from the world if you but name him more.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir Geoffry Iolt just arriv'd, desires you would oblige him with your Presence.

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: I'll wait upon him, and do you hear, be Wise and Circumspect, with him I dare to trust you.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: Yes, Wise enough to leave your surly Humour: did I for this take you to my Embraces, did with that Holy (Curse on the fatall hour, and Curse on me for yielding thus to an Eternall Bondage) Tye of Matrimony? Knit both our Souls together? What shall I doe? I must be free again. Sir Generalls Charms have won so much upon me that now I dare, (prompted by the Ill usage of a Cruell Husband) act all he has desired. This very hour I will disguise my self, and with that stock of Jewells I have left, fly to my Amorous Lover, and in his Arms repeat our stoln Delights. But here comes that cruell Clog of Matrimony, Husband.

div.stage: Enter Contentious Surly and Sir Geoffry Jolthead.

sp.speaker: Surley.
sp.p: Sir Geoffry Welcome, you know I am one of as few Ceremonies as Words, which both I think are needless to a Friend.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: They are indeed Mr. Surly, for my part I hate 'em, I love nothing in the World but brisk Wine, Compleat French Fashions, and Aery young Women, is that your Wife Sir?

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: One I am forc'd to call so.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: She is very handsome, by my Honour I must salute her. Lady accept this kiss from a Country Magistrate, one who admires any thing that belongs to my Dear and Respective Friend Surly.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: I am happy then in being his Sir.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p:
You are indeed, that word of Humility sounds so pleasantly and sweetly, that by Iove I must [Kisses her again. have another. I love a Lady that payes Obedience and Respect
to her Lord and Master: a Husband is the Head, the very top Branch of the Family.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: I look upon him so indeed.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Again, again, Lord how this Duty Charms me! let me Embrace you for an hour together.

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: How now! why I shall foster up another Snake to sting my Bosome, and one who through simplicity will do't before my Face.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: I hope my Wisedome and Circumspection as he calls it, will make the top Branch of the Family a Buck of the first Head.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: As I was going to say, Mr. Surly, your Wife is a very Dutifull, Religious, and by my Honour, a very obliging Lady, your London Women kiss with such Art, and so much Magnificence, that they almost Ravish us Country Gentlemen: did you teach her that turn, and that thrust of the Lip ha? by Iove 'tis most Delicious.

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: No Sir.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Then she is Witty too, Lord how I admire a Witty Lady! learn that touch your self! let me be ravish'd quite.

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: Death and Confusion, this is worse than t'other, this is a meer Stallion, I shall be the Branch I find it, he tops upon her still, and she Receives it, Sir Geoffry.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: I beg your Pardon Mr. Surly. I vow your Wife has such a Charming way of Kissing, and presses it so close, I had forgot my self.

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: And so She has—I think, have you no shame, thou Impudent'st of Women?

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: Shame Sir!

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: Yes shame.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: For what?

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: To let the World behold your loose desires, you kiss with Art and Pleasure.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: You bid me use him kindly, bid me be Wise and Circumspect, and said that you durst trust him with me, and truely if you dare venture that, I dare trust my self with him.

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: Oh Impudence!

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p:
You would have me turn the Cheek and blush when he comes near me, as if I were afraid his Beard would hurt me.
No Mr. Surly, I us'd him kindly out of respect to you: and a thing once well done, is better than twice ill.

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: Distraction seize her! get you to your Chamber.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: I'm gone Sir, and from you for ever.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: What, send your Wife away and not give your Friend notice? 'twas unkindly done.

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: Her business call'd her.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: I'faith She kisses smartly.

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: I am glad to hear it.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: And is all Air too, and for her breath—

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: No more of that Sir Geoffry, I am glad I have any thing to pleasure you—Pox on him, I cannot forbid him the house for shame, nor must he stay to plague me.—

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Come, come, come, I find you are melancholy, let's to a Tavern, a glass or two of Champain will make us kiss and caper, and get us a stomach to our Dinners.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: My Wife made an Assignation to meet Amorous in the Garden?

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: It is nothing but truth I'll promise you, for his man Spywell gave me money not only to be a Confederate, but to steal the Key of the Garden gate, that he as well as my Lady might enter in and out at pleasure.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Did he so, did he so? Nay, then there is Treason plotting against my honour, I find there is, and did you get the Key for him Bramble?

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Did you so Rogue? out upon thee for a Villain, a Traytor, a meer foot Pad, a Setter, Devil; you gave him the Key did you? I'll key you with a Pox.

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: Hold Sir, hold, you will make Mummy of me else.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: I will make a Devil of thee, what, my own Servant be a Traitor?

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: I thought no harm in it, as I hope to be—

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p:
Beaten did you not? what, give the Key of your Masters Cabinet, his Jewells, his all he has, and yet think no harm? However come along, conduct me to the place where I may see 'em both, or I will beat you swindgingly, nay, when I have seen 'em, I will make you beat the villain, and then
beat you for not beating him enough, come along Rascall.

div.head: SCENE A Bedchamber.
div.stage: Sir Generall Amorous, and Eudoria sitting as in Discourse, they rise and come upon the Stage.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: How shall I make amends for this great blessing? if all the Services of Life, (which I'll devote to you) can make the least, I vow to use 'em all; and spend no time but in the company of you, or your Idea which cannot be absent from a Lovers mind, when his Mistress is so kind, so Charming, and so—

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Nay, do not flatter me, I am but as you see, my Face may pass, and those which love it not, let 'em seek out a better; I am no whining Lover, I hate those puling Fops, I love a man that gains me by Intrigue, a minute stoln is all the happiness of our mortality.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: We will have many then, revell in Joys, and steal a thousand pleasures, I have a Brain was never barren yet, especially in any Love Projection.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Thanks to your subtle Man, your vigilant Spywell, his Name was not giv'n him for nothing.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: True Madam, I confess he has a ready Wit, but never yet durst undertake an Action, before the Mass was cast by me: he only works and thus divides the whole as our Occasions happen, the drift of which is to obtain your Love.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Which Purchas'd, will perhaps be answer'd with a scorn.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Never, O never Madam; it is impossible such glorious Charms should meet the least neglect, you are all Goodness, and Entrance at every look my Soul.

sp.speaker: Spyw.
sp.p: Haste, or you're lost for ever, your Jealous Husband prompted by his Rage, comes first to search the Chamber, he is all fire and nothing can allay him.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: What shall we doe?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Stand here and meet his Fury.

sp.speaker: Spyw.
sp.p: O by no means, is there no secret Chamber, no place of safety for you?

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Only one, this door leads to a Gallery which is as dark as night, from whence sometimes he fancies are groans heard, which he declares for Truth, and now and then relates what dreadfull Monsters, Ghosts and Devils he in his Bed hath seen, all being only Fancies, idle Dreams; thither we will enter, and as we goe I'll give you a Disguise which I have alwaies ready, and if he chance to enter with a Light tumble both down together.

sp.speaker: Spyw.
sp.p: It shall be done, fear not, haste, haste, I hear him coming.

div.stage: Enter Sir Arthur and Bramble, Bramble with a Light.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: On, on, you villain on,— [Looks about the Room. not here by Heaven, nor here,— [Breaks open one Door. nor here.— [Breaks open another. She is in the Garden that's certain, stay, stay, hold, hold, here is a Gallery, a Teneberian Gullet, which I dare not enter, but Bramble shall, in, in, in there Rascall, search every place, nay every Corner, or meet my high displeasure.

div.stage: Bramble Enters, is Tumbled down by Spywell, rowls out and is followed by Spywell as a Ghost, Arthur seeing him, runs off crying the Devil, the Devil, &c. and Bramble crawls off.

sp.speaker: Spyw.
sp.p: Come, come, you may venture to come out now.

div.stage: Enter Eudoria and Sir Generall Amorous.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: He's gone, as full of fear as Jelousy, Eudoria this plot was yours, and henceforth to you I'll own my Preservation.

sp.speaker: Spyw.
sp.p: This is no time to talk, Madam haste to your Bed, and there pretend a sleep, I know you want not fitting words t'excuse so small an absence if he should chance to search and find you. And you Sir, haste to your Chamber, I know that's the next Randezvous after the Garden.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Farewell, my Prayers and Love attend you.

sp.speaker: Twif.
sp.p: Nay, nay, come, come, come, my pretty Cousins, upon my honour and all that, you are both Beauties, but especially Lady Cousin, you as the Eldest ought to have most praise, and i'faith you deserve it nobly, and when saw you my Lord Iohn, and his Lady Mary, ha?

sp.speaker: Emel.
sp.p: I know 'em not.

sp.speaker: Twif.
sp.p:
What, not my very good Friend and Honourable Cousin my Lord Iohn? that's strange indeed; why, he was my Fathers Cobler, but afterwards by Care and Prudence, good Custome and so forth, he became an Alderman, and then—
Enter Sir Arthur and Bramble. what, my Honourable Cousin Sir Arthur, I vow I am glad to see you: my Lady Mary is very considerably well, and truely I believe we shall have Affairs put into a very good order, and Cousin Arthur your two Daughters and I have been entertaining Discourse upon a very considerable subject.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Pox of your subjects. Emelia, where is Eudoria?

sp.speaker: Emel.
sp.p: In her Chamber Sir.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: 'Tis false, all, all are Traytors, every one conspires my Ruine and Disgrace, but you shall pay for it Villain you shall, I'll firk you i'faith, you must tell Lies with a Pox, get you from my sight you Varlet.

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: So I will, and from your Service too; the Devil shall live with such a Master for me, farewell Sir, may the Pox and your own Horns choak you.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Is he gone, is the Villain gone?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: What did he say?

sp.speaker: Twif.
sp.p: Something about Horns and Pox, but by my Honour Coz I believe he's Frantick, for what has a Clown to doe either with Pox or Horns? they are Ornaments only for Court and City.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: But Emelia, Flora, nay good Girles tell me where, where, where is Eudoria, where is my new Lodger?

sp.speaker: Emel.
sp.p: As for Sir Amorous I know not, but for Eudoria I saw her in her Chamber.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: And so did I Sir Amorous.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Nay then 'tis pretty well, 'tis pretty well: I am almost mad dear Girles, this Rogue Bramble has Cashier'd my Wits, Pox of the Garden key, but 'tis no matter Emelia I have a Husband for you, a Rich and Understanding Husband.

sp.speaker: Emel.
sp.p: Nay, if he be but Rich I'll bate his Understanding, that is too troublesome a Companion for a Woman.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: All, all of the same Brood be Heaven, not one Chast Woman in a Kingdom, if there be one 'tis a Miracle.

sp.speaker: Emel.
sp.p: This is the Curse of Wedlock, hourly Jealousies and daily Troubles, if ever I marry it shall be one both Deaf, Dumb, Lame and Blind.
sp.l: They're all but Complements for hourly Strife,
And with new Troubles daily fill the Life
Of her who's such a sot to be a Wife.

div.trailer: The End of the First Act.

div.head: SCENE St. Iames's.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p:
MY Thoughts are all on fire, my Pulse beats swift, and every Motion ushers a new thought, I'm all Desire and Love, and fain would reap those pleasures are in View, oh Jelousy how dost thou wrong that Love might be enjoy'd without the least Suspect, how many various waies do we Conspire to blind his greedy Eyes! I wonder Bramble stayes so long, our hasty separation hindred a new Appointment, which I was forc'd to send by one I would not trust, did he not hate Sir Arthur.
Enter Bramble. Bramble the News?

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: The News Sir!

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Yes, how doth Eudoria?

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: Soft, soft Sir, you think it is nothing to get News out of a Ladies Chamber where her Husband is the Jaylor, I was there Sir.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: As you know a merry fellow may pass any where.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: So Sir, but what is this to the purpose?

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: Nay, it was nothing to the purpose that is certain.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: How wretched this slave makes me, did you not see her?

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: I saw her.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Well, and what said she then?

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: Not a word Sir.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: How! not a Word?

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: Proves her the better temper'd, for Women should be seen more than they are heard. She was asleep Sir.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: You should have waked her then; such another oppornuity lost would be enough to ruine half a Kingdome.

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: I durst not venture that Sir, for fear Sir Arthur should have heard me, and then you know what follows: but I stood still awhile, and presently I might perceive Eudoria yawn, and stir, and rub her Eyes and then—

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: She spoke the kindest words, oh let me hear 'em.

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: Not one indeed Sir, and yet I know her mind as well as if I were in her Belly.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: You said but now she did not speak a word.

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: But she gave certain Signs, and that's as good.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Can you conceive by Signs?

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: Yes very well Sir, even from an Infant, did you ne're know that? I was the happiest Child in all our Country, I was born of a Dumb woman.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: Stark Dumb Sir: my Father had a Rare bargain of her, a Rich penniworth, there would have been but too much money given for her, a Justice of Peace was about her, but my Father being then Constable carried her before him.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: What were the Signs she gave?

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: Many and good Sir. Imprimis, she first gap'd, but that I guess'd was done for want of Air; then she cast up her Eyes and wink'd, as who should say bid Sir Amorous come at twilight: then look'd upon her Watch and twice she nodded, as who should say, the hour will come, that I shall make two Noddies of my Keepers.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: A Third of thee, is this your Mother Tongue? my hopes are much the wiser for this Language, there is no such Curse in Love as an Arrant Ass.

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: O yes Sir, yes, an Arrant Whore's far worse.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Begone, is this the good you do me? his Love is wretched and most distrest that must make use of Fools.

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: Fool to my Face from this, and be beaten by the other? that's unreasonable; I will be a Knave one day for this trick, or it shall cost me a Fall, though it be from a Gibbet. I'll be out of the Precincts of Fools if I live but two daies to an end, I will turn Rascall presently, the best sort of which are Gipseys; for that is the high way to the daintiest Knave that ever Mothers son took journey to. O those dear Gipseys they live the merriest Lives, eat sweet stoln Hens, pluck'd over Pales and Hedges by a Twitch. They are never without a plump and lovely Goose, or dainty Sow pig, those things I saw with my own Eyes to day, they call 'em Vanities and trifling Pilfries, oh they are the Wittiest Thieves, I'll stay no longer, but go and steal something presently, and so bring my self acquainted with them.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Nothing I fear so much as in the time of my dull absence, and the idle Frensie of my Messenger, her Husband will come to know our Loves, and by secret threats and promises regain her Affection, there is the Mischief, I have no Enemy like him, and though his Policy dissemble me a welcome, no mans hate can be greater than his to me.

sp.speaker: Spyw.
sp.p:
Now is your only time t'enjoy the freedome Sir of Conversation. After Eudoria parted to her Bed, I watched the Jealous Husband and dog'd him from the Garden to her Chamber,
where when he found her he leapt for very Joy, then wept, and leap'd again, at last he timerously strove to wake her, which being done he fell upon his Knees and beg'd her to forgive him; hung on her Neck and seem'd to be Transported.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: How can this quench those Flames of Love I feel, or help me to Enjoyment?

sp.speaker: Spyw.
sp.p: No sooner was his Pardon sign'd with Kisses, but from her sight he flung to seek you out, that you might make it perfect.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: All this but ushers Torment, not Reliefe.

sp.speaker: Spyw.
sp.p: He gone, I entered towards the fair Eudoria, and with such moving words as I could utter, painted the Flame Sir of your vigorous Love; she lent a gentle Ear to what I said, and sighing bid you meet her in the Grove behind the Garden gate.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Oh Happiness!

sp.speaker: Spyw.
sp.p: Where Mask'd Sir, and disguis'd like a Town Gipsy she would attend your Pleasure.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: O let me hug you close, I could (methinks) squeeze you into my Soul, the News you've brought has made me all a Flame, rais'd my desires to such a mighty pitch, that as I'm falling t'wards my Sea of pleasure. I shall tast on the way all, all the bliss of Life.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Sir Generall Amorous well met, well met i'faith, I vow I am glad to see you; my Wife poor— Amorous stands melancholy. What, angry man? come, come, I know the reason, I was a little Jealous, Fack I was, but it is off again; nay, now you are no true Friend, what, angry for a Continuando?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: I am not Sir, especially with you, yet who can shun the Crosses of the World, or help—

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Help, what Crosses? I am the best at helping of Crosses of any man in Europe; come tell me your Grievances, you shall, you shall.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Sir, they are in my Power to tell, but not in your Will t'effect.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Not in my Will t'effect? by Eudoria's honesty but it shall be in my Will, What is't?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: By my frequent disappointments, and my many urgent occasions for mony, I am at this time necessitated for a hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Hum, hum, a hundred pound? 'tis a swindging summe indeed, and out of my power not will to lend you; however here's a Ring, a diamond Ring it is, and will go near to pawn for fifty Guinneys, take that, before you have spent it all, I shall be furnished doubt not.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Sir I accept your proffer, and for your security the Deeds of all my Lands shall be delivered, till then farewell.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Shall be delivered? ay but when? I have done bravely now, lent fifty pound upon a shall be delivered; yet o' my conscience he is an honest Gentleman; he has honesty and civility writ on his face, he has indeed; he is not like our whoring, swearing Sparks of the times, who make it their practice to dub Cuckolds, and then out of civility be the Child's Godfather.

div.stage: Enter Sir Jeoffrey Jolthead and Contentious Surly.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Why, now Mr. Surly we look like men, methinks I could caper and leap, and kiss and play, and do every thing with a Lady: oh this wine, this wine is a very pleasant element.

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: It is indeed.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: What Sir Arthur Twilight, and how does my pretty little flearing Misses ha? can they kiss smartly and turn up the lip ha?

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: Pox of this Fool, he will proclaim my shame to all the World.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Can they Boy, can they?

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: They can do every thing belongs to the Sex no doubt Sir Geoffrey.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: I vow they are pretty Wags, I love 'em dearly; shall I see 'em?

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Yes when you please Sir Geoffrey. Mr. Surly you look clouded: pox of sorrow I say, it is enough for superannuated Cuckolds to be melancholy, not such as you and I, we are free from it.

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: I would I were. [Aside.] Sure he knows nothing to the contrary.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: 'Tis a great torment to be jealous sure, to think a very shadow at Noon-day can do the act we dream of: to frown on all, even our best of friends; turn off our Lodgers, cashier our Servants, swear at our Maids, slander our Children.

div.stage: As Sir Arthur talks, Contentious Surly walks, Sir Arthur following him.

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: Curse on this Ribaldry, what's this to me, am I the man you aim at?

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: No, no Sir, no.

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: Am I the mark you level all these arrows at?

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: No Sir, no.

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: Why do you bellow in my ears the name of Cuckold then?

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Because there is pleasure in it, methinks they are the prettiest old decrepit Creatures in Europe: but Mr. Surly I have done, come shall's drink a glass of Wine together? let us be brisk and merry, shall we ha?

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Well said Mr. Arthur, you are the same man still, the merry man i'faith, and could I warrant you—but 'tis no matter, come Mr. Surly.

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: I care Sir for no more, my business lies at home.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: A pox of home, thou hast a Wife at home, that can I'le warrant you manage affairs without the help of Husband, come, come, you shall go.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Do do, i'fack, Mr. Surly you are good company, and I love good company with all my heart, come come, let's to the Tavern, and there talk of our Wives.

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: If I go, I bar that discourse.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: It shall, it shall, come, come, we will not name 'em, we will not name 'em.

div.head: SCENE The Fields.
div.stage: Enter Petulant Easy disguised like a Gypsie.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p:
I'm happily escap'd, not one pursues me, this shape's too cunning for 'em, and if I can but find Sir General, then all my hopes are crown'd. This is the Gypsies place of meeting, I wonder they are not come yet, what will become of me in this shape without my strange Companions? if I know where to go
I'm no dissembler, and I'de not lose that part of woman for such a trifle.

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: Oh excellent! by this light here's one of 'em, by your leave Gypsie, pray how far off is your Company?

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: Oh happiness, this is the merry fellow Sir Arthur Twilight keeps, I'le send him speedily to Sir General with the news of my so strange and fortunate escape, and hee'l provide my safety at an instant. [Aside.] Do you not serve Sir Arthur Twilight?

sp.speaker: Bram.
sp.p: Who, I serve, Gypsie? I scorn your motion, and if the rest of your company give me no better words, I will hinder them the stealing of more Pullen then fifty Poulterers were ever worth, and prove a heavier enemy to all their Pig-Booties; they shall travail like Iews, and never get a Sow by the ear. I serve? I scorn to serve any body, I am more Gypsie-minded then so, though my face look of a Christian colour, if my belly were ripp'd up, you should find my heart as black as any patch about ye: the truth is, I am as errand a thief as the proudest in the company, I will except none, I am run away from my Master in the state of a fool, and till I am a perfect knave I never mean to return again.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: I am never the happier for this fortune now, it did but mock me.

sp.speaker: Bram.
sp.p: But here comes my last Master, I must not be seen.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: Yonder's Sir Amorous, O happy hour, my blushes come apace to shrowd my shame, thus let me hide 'em from him.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: This is certainly she. Madam I am glad I have the happiness of this occasion to meet you here alone, far from the eyes of any Jealous Husband.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: I have long wish'd it, and now I fear some strange mischance will cross us.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Fear nothing Madam, but let's retire, the hasty Sun will soon withdraw its lustre, and leave us Lovers in a bed of darkness, where we shall be wrap'd in pleasures.

sp.speaker: Bram.
sp.p: Ha is he gone? what, and the Gypsie too? then am I lost again.

div.stage: Enter Eudoria disguis'd like a Gypsie.

sp.speaker: Eudo.
sp.p: Who's that, Bramble? then on my shrowd and hide me from his sight.

div.stage: Enter a company of Gypsies, men and women with booties of Hens, &c. dancing and singing ridiculously, Bramble seems overjoy'd.

sp.speaker: Bram.
sp.p: O sweet, they deserve to be hang'd for so ravishing of me.

sp.speaker: Eudo.
sp.p: What will become of me? if I seem fearfull now, or offer sudden flight, I shall betray my self, I must do neither.

sp.speaker: C. Gip.
sp.p: Ousabell, Camcheteroon, Puscatelion, Howsdrows.

sp.speaker: 2. Gip.
sp.p: Rumbos Stragadelion, alla Piskitch in sows Clows.

sp.speaker: Bram.
sp.p: Piskitch in sows Clows! I shall never keep a good tongue in my head till I get this Language.

sp.speaker: C. Gip.
sp.p: Umbra Fill, Kevoliden, Magropie.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: I love your Language well but understand it not.

sp.speaker: C. Gip.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: I am but lately turn'd to your profession, yet from my youth I ever lov'd it dearly; steal I can, it was a thing I ever was brought up to; my Father was a Miller, my Mother a Tayler's Widow.

sp.speaker: Bram.
sp.p: She is a thief on both sides.

sp.speaker: C. Gip.
sp.p: Give me thy hand, we have not a more true bred thief among us.

sp.speaker: Bram.
sp.p: Pray take me into some grace amongst you, for though I claim no goodness from my Parents to help me into your society, I had two Uncles that were both hang'd for Robberies, and a brave Cut-purse to my Cosen German: if Kindred will be taken, I am as near of kin to a thief as any of you that had Fathers and Mothers.

sp.speaker: C. Gip.
sp.p: What is it thou requirest noble Cosin?

sp.speaker: Bram.
sp.p: Cosin? nay if we are so near of kin already now we are sober, we shall be sworn brothers when we are drunk: the naked truth is, I would be made a Gipsie as fast as you could devise.

sp.speaker: C. Gip.
sp.p: A Gipsie?

sp.speaker: Bram.
sp.p: Yes with all the speed you can sir, the very sight of those stoln Hens, eggs me forward notably.

sp.speaker: C. Gip.
sp.p: Stretch forth thy hand Cuz, art thou fortunate?

sp.speaker: Bram.
sp.p: Nay I cannot tell that my self, I have sometimes found mony in old shoes, but if I had not stoln more then I found, I had had but a scurvy thin cheek'd fortune of it.

sp.speaker: C. Gip.
sp.p: Here's a fair table.

sp.speaker: Bram.
sp.p: So hath many a man that hath given over house-keeping, a fair table when there is neither cloth nor meat upon it.

sp.speaker: C. Gip.
sp.p: What a brave line of life is here! look Gipsies.

div.stage: Whilst they discourse, the Gipsies pick his pocket.

sp.speaker: Bram.
sp.p: I have known as brave a life end in an halter.

sp.speaker: C. Gip.
sp.p: But thou art born to precious fortune.

sp.speaker: Bram.
sp.p: Ha! am I so?

sp.speaker: C. Gip.
sp.p: Bette Buckettos.

sp.speaker: Bram.
sp.p: How! to beat bucks?

sp.speaker: C. Gip.
sp.p: Stealee Bacons.

sp.speaker: Bram.
sp.p: Oh to steal bacon, that is the better fortune of the two indeed.

sp.speaker: C. Gip.
sp.p: Thou wilt be shortly Captain of the Gipsies.

sp.speaker: Bram.
sp.p: I would you'd make me Corporal in the mean time, or Standard-bearer to the womens Regiment.

sp.speaker: C. Gip.
sp.p: Much may be done for love.

sp.speaker: Bram.
sp.p: Nay here is some mony, I know an Office comes not all for love. [Searches his pockets but finds none. A pox of your lime-twigs you have it already.

sp.speaker: C. Gip.
sp.p: It lies but here in cash for thy own use boy.

sp.speaker: Bram.
sp.p: Nay if it lie there once, I shall hardly come to the fingering on't in hast, yet make me an apt scholar, and I care not, teach me but so much Gipsie to steal as much from another, and Old Nick do you good with that.

sp.speaker: C. Gip.
sp.l: Thou shalt have all thy heart requires.
First here's a Girl for thy desires. [Gives him a woman Gipsie.
Look you prove industrious dealers,
To serve the Commonwealth with stealers,
That th'unhous'd Race of Fortune-tellers,
May never fail to cheat Town-dwellers:
Or to our universal grief,
Leave Country Fairs without a thief.
This is all you have to doe,
Save every hour a filch or two:
Which hoping you'll observe, to trie thee,
With Rusty Bacon thus I Gipsie-fie thee.

sp.speaker: Bram.
sp.p: Do you use to doe it with Bacon?

sp.speaker: C. Gip.
sp.p: Evermore.

sp.speaker: Bram.
sp.p: By this light the Rats will take me now for some Hogscheek, and eat up my face when I am asleep: I shall have ne'r a bit left by to morrow morning, and lying open mouth'd as I us'd to do, I shall look for all the world like a mouse-trap baited with bacon.

sp.speaker: C. Gip.
sp.l: Why here's a face like thine so done,
Only grain'd in by the Sun.
And this, and these.

sp.speaker: Bram.
sp.p: Faith then there is a company of Bacon-faces of us; we are a kind of conscionable people, and it was well thought upon to steal bacon and black our faces with it; 'tis like one that commits sin, and writes his faults in his forehead.

sp.speaker: C. Gip.
sp.p: Wit whither wilt thou?

sp.speaker: Bram.
sp.p: Marry to the next pocket I can come at, and if it be a Landlords, I wish a whole years rent in it: is this my In Dock out Nettle? what's Gipsie for her?

sp.speaker: C. Gip.
sp.p: Your Doxie she.

sp.speaker: Bram.
sp.p: Oh right, are you my Doxie, sirrah?

sp.speaker: Wo. Gip.
sp.l: I'll be thy Doxie and thy Dell,
With thee I'll live, for thee I'll steal.
From Fair to Fair, from Wake to Wake,
I'll ramble still for thy sweet sake.

sp.speaker: Bram.
sp.p: Oh dainty fine Doxie, she speaks the Language as familiarly as if she were begot of a Canter.

div.l: Thus hand in hand let's hem him round,
And dance a measure on the ground.
We'll frolick first, then part from hence,
Each with his stock of impudence:
To Towns, to Cities, Fairs, and Fields,
And see what profit each one yields.
Then to our Rendezvous wee'l fly.
Be brisk, be drunk, be kind and die.
div.stage: Here they dance. At the end of the dance, Enter Contentious Surly, Sir Arthur Twilight, and Sir Jeoffrey Jolthead, the Gipsies seeing them, run off all but Eudoria and Bramble.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p:
Hey day, hey day, what a surprize is this! [Eudoria offers to go, is hindred by Sir Arthur.
Nay, nay, Gipsie you shall not go, i'fack you shall not, I long to kiss a Gipsie, I do indeed; I am not so old yet but I can shake my leg under a hedge I'll warrant you, come, come, Gipsie, pull off your false face, and tell me my fortune.

div.stage: [Takes her aside and shows his hand.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: And can you tell fortunes sirrah?

sp.speaker: Bram.
sp.p: Culvario, legamuttanio.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: What a pox is that?

sp.speaker: Bram.
sp.p: Shouldramaton, Katathumpton, Rob, bob, a Tumbrell.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: That Tumbrell I understand being a Magistrate, on, fellow, on, what say you to my hand?

sp.speaker: Bram.
sp.p: Chitteroon High Gulleroon, Filcheroon, purse Fulleroon, Ousabell Camcheteroon, Puscatelion Howsdrows.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: What a devil is this?

sp.speaker: Bram.
sp.p: Rumbos Straggadelion, alla piskitch in sows clows umbra fill Kevolliden Magropie.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Pox on ye, speak English, or I'll make you, tell me of Magropies?

sp.speaker: Bram.
sp.p: You are—

div.stage: Stares in his face, and all this while pretends to pick his pocket, but is discovered.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Ha Rogue, ha, is this your Piskitch in sows clows, and your Magropies? I'll Magropie you with a pox.

sp.speaker: Bram.
sp.p: As I hope to be sav'd this is the first time, I am but a young Gipsie yet; alas I was Sir Arthur's Bramble till he beat me, and then I ran away, and entred my self amongst 'em.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: I'll enter you as I am a Magistrate.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: I'fack thou art a pretty Rogue, tells me all true by heaven: Oh I could eat your eyes out! On, on.

sp.speaker: Eudo.
sp.p: Y'are an insufficient decrepit whoremaster, and deserve were I your wife to be—

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p:
Chronicled, Ido indeed: but women may say what
they please, they may indeed. Come, come, let you and I retire, yonder is a delicate hedge, where we will communicate all our good Parts together, we will indeed.

sp.speaker: Eudo.
sp.p: What before you see my face?

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: No matter, no matter, you have good signs, good hands, good hips, and I believe good every thing; come, come, come, let us lose no time, here's money before-hand, I'gad methinks I am a very vigorous Lover.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: But I hope, to see my face, now you have so generously expos'd your gold, would be no trouble.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: None in the world: introth it would raise, it would elevate my spirits to a height, it would indeed, and then I shall—

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: What, Sir Arthur [Discovers her self, all are amazed. Be a perjur'd false dissembling Hypocrite! are these your daily actions, these your haunts? could nothing but a Gipsie serve your turn? is age so hot, so fierce in his desires? have I with tears wept if you were but absent, mourn'd like a turtle when my mate was from me, and all for this return?

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: This is some trick, some trick upon my life, and ten to one my honour is concern'd in't; I'll after the Gipsies, perhaps my wife is amongst 'em, I'll see, and search every man and woman in the company but I will find her out.

sp.speaker: Bram.
sp.p: My Mistress a Gipsie? nay then there is hopes for me.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Keep off, now I abhor you.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Nay dear Spouse, 'twas but a freak, a little freak indeed.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Come, come, forgive him Madam, 'troth I have done as much my self.

sp.speaker: Bram.
sp.p: Pray Madam forgive him that Sir Geoff. may forgive me.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Nay, nay, dear Chuck, what, be your Husband's mortal enemy? why, who would have taken you for a Gipsie? Nay, nay, come, you shall forgive me.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: I do Sir, but have a care for the future.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: I will never look upon a woman besides thy self again, indeed I will not. Sir Geoffrey, you must forgive Bramble too, then all are friends.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: With all my heart, but have a care hereafter.

sp.speaker: Bram.
sp.p: I'll warrant you Sir.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Come Sir Geoff. you shall along with me and see Emelia.
sp.l: How more then happy is the marriage life,
When man is blest with such a vertuous Wife.

div.head: ACT III.
SCENE A Grove.
div.stage: Enter as out of it, Sir General Amorous, and Easy mask'd.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: THIS is the greatest blessing Heav'n (and you) could give me. How many minutes have we had of precious sweet delight! Oh let me dwell upon these hands a while, and breath my soul into each trilling Pore: thy melting lips have made me all a charm, and when I cast my arms about thy neck, I thought I grasp'd a God; the darkness of the Covert could not shade thy piercing beauty from me, for through those thick and darksome Clouds of Night, I could behold the glances of thy Eyes, which shot fresh joys into my panting heart.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: You're pleas'd to jest.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Not I by Heaven, all, all I say is earnest; pull back that Cloud, and let me view your glories: let me behold you in the height of blushes, that I may say you charm at every Action. [Easy pulls off her mask, Generous starts. Ha! have I embrac'd a stale, a cast off Amoret, is this the hopes I had of fair Eudoria, have I bestow'd a Ring of fifty pound upon I know not what?

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: What ayle you Sir?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Nothing Madam, nothing, onely the apprehension of the danger, and the mistrust your Husband will have of you when he shall find you absent, I must confess did something start my spirits, but now 'tis off again. But oh! the Ring!

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: Name not that senseless thing again, a Husband is e'ne a clog of life, I'm of a humour free, and unconfin'd, and court for pleasure in the man I love.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: True Madam, 'tis most sweet; when love and freedom meet, a Husband is a kind of dull Animal, created to bear the name of Father, whilest we happy men enjoy with freedom what he fondly thinks himself monopolizeth.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: Then they're so jealous too.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p:
They are indeed, and that first prompts their wives to new desires: I never yet knew a man jealous, but he had the just rewards his madness merited.
Enter Contentious Surly. Heavens! here's your Husband coming, on, on with the mask, and haste home with all the speed you can before morning, expect me to give you freedom. Exit Easy, Surly going after her, is stop'd by General Amorous.
Mr. Surly your servant. I vow I am happy in finding you in this solitary place, my thoughts wanted companions.

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: And so they are like still, I cannot stay.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Were your haste requisite I would not stop you, but with your friend you might dispense some time.

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: I cannot, nor I will not.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Indeed you must sir.

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: Must?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Yes sir you must: I have not forgot how in your last frantick fit you pleas'd to stain my honour, and with such words.

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: I have no leisure now.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: To fight I know you have not, nor never had; you wear a sword indeed, but for what use I know not, unless to frighten fools, bully with cowards, or draw on every Linkboy.

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: Prithee, I can stay no longer.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: He's gone as full of rage as jealousie, pray Heaven he overtake her not, but sure she has more wit then to go the direct path, which he I'm sure will follow. Was ever man so cheated? how came I to mistake Eudoria, and light upon this Easy? it must needs be the treachery of Spywell.

sp.speaker: Spy.
sp.p: Was ever man so unfortunate?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Was ever man so treacherous?

sp.speaker: Spy.
sp.p: To have an Assignation from a Lady, and shun the blessing of it.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p:
I am plain and do not speak in Hieroglyphicks, did not you send Petulant Easy disguis'd, as you told me Eudoria
design'd to be, to the place appointed for our meeting.

sp.speaker: Spy.
sp.p: Not I by Heaven.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Then the Devil did, that's certain; for I no sooner came to th' Rendezvous, but Easy habited and mask'd as you described Eudoria, with open Arms received me, and led me to this Grove; where after a few common ceremonies, love-toys, and the like, I presented her with a Ring I borrowed of Sir Arthur Twilight, still taking her for Eudoria, but coming to the light, and the dark Cloud withdrawn, I found my strange mistake.

sp.speaker: Spy.
sp.p: The same hapned to Eudoria, who full of love came to the place appointed, and there unfortunately met with Sir Arthur.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Confusion!

sp.speaker: Spy.
sp.p: He mistaking her for a Gipsie, made a deal of ridiculous Love to her, which she accepted, but coming to the height of all his passion, and fill'd with a licentious kind of Dotage, she discovered her self to the old Lecher, who was glad to make his peace on any terms.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Oh I could grasp her now into my soul! she is the most deserving of womenkind, but how to let her know the strange mistake, is past my power to imagine.

sp.speaker: Spy.
sp.p: Leave that to me, haste to Sir Arthur Twilight, and there pretend (as you may very well) a Journey out of Town, and by the way declare your love to Easy, and hatred to Contentious Surly, tell him you long to be reveng'd, and know no way but one, which is to take his Wife with you.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Make him a Pander?

sp.speaker: Spy.
sp.p: Wee'l do't ne'er fear, he loves to view a Cuckold, but hates to see himself; Come, let's be gone, I'll tell you as we walk, with what you must possess him: as for Eudoria, leave her to me, if I prepare her not may I never design again.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Thou art a real servant, and lovest thy Master's pleasure.
sp.l: How many various Charms round Women move!
Each has some strange Intreague to make us Love.

div.head: SCENE Sir Arthur's House.
div.stage: Enter Sir Geoffry Jolthead, Emelia and Flora.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: But what say you Ladies, how could you affect my person? am I not all Air, ha? why, we Country Magistrates are such taking things, that you Londoners run almost stark mad of us. I am as sprightly as any bawdy Citizen of you all; I can drink, I can swear, I can roar, I can serenade, and besides all that, I can—but 'tis no matter.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Nay there is no doubt Sir, but you are are all vigour, and methinks I could love a Country Gentleman with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Eme.
sp.p: And so could I, especially a Country Magistrate, they look with so much Grace, and sit at the Bench just like—

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: We do so, we do so indeed,—just like what, my Dear?

sp.speaker: Eme.
sp.p: A Baboon looking an Alderman's head.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Out upon thee wag, a Baboon is a beastly lascivious Creature: but go on, go on, you have leave to jeast.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: I am not of your mind Sister, I love a Magistrate, especially when he is asleep, he nods so prettily, and then he is so quiet, unless now and then he snore out a learned Sentence.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Still, still you are wags, meer wags i'faith; but go on, go on, methinks I love to hear you.

sp.speaker: Eme.
sp.p: I've done jeasting Sir, alas my fit lasts but a little while, and then I am so melancholy; and yet methinks I could love you, would you forbear that hard hearted trick of seeing women whip'd at the House of Correction.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: I never use it, indeed I do not, but I know some of your London Justices do, it is a kind of pleasure to 'em, and I dare say saves 'em many a crown in the year.

sp.speaker: Emel.
sp.p: Oh now I love you strangely, could you—but I dare not speak before my Sister—Could you love me Sir?

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Beyond the world, why I could eat you Madam.

sp.speaker: Emel.
sp.p: What and keep me like a Lady?

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Oh like a Countess, you shall have all, all that your heart desires, and live so pleasantly.

sp.speaker: Emel.
sp.p: But would you never turn me off?

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Never, never by this hand.

sp.speaker: Emel.
sp.p: Nor keep another?

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.l: Sooner a Devil, believe me Madam—
This is the yieldingest little Female I ever saw.

sp.speaker: Emel.
sp.p: I'm loth to try you though, you men are so deceitfull.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Courtiers and Shopkeepers, I grant you, they seldome or never keep their words, but we Countrymen are as true as steel.

sp.speaker: Emel.
sp.p: How shall we come together?

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: How! as man and woman should.

sp.speaker: Emel.
sp.p: But by what means?

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Ay by what means,—I think some disguise—

sp.speaker: Emel.
sp.p: You've thought upon it, habit your self like a Quaker, and come at twelve this night, you'l see a candle in my window, hem twice, and I'll come down and let you in, the habit's grave and will keep off suspicion.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: It will indeed, oh let me kiss your hand.

sp.speaker: Emel.
sp.l: Anon you shall enough, farewell.
You shall be Miss'd Sir Geoffry, or I'll lose my aim.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Was ever Country Magistrate so fortunate? sure never. I am an Adonis, that's certain.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: My Sister and you have had a long discourse Sir.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.l: Something we did talk of, but not much.
This Chicken has a mind to be doing too I find it. [Aside.
Alas she is all anger, and looks upon me as the Devil look'd over Lincoln.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: I should have been kinder had you made your addresses to me; but her Charms are so great, so many, and so powerfull, it was not in the power of man to stand against 'em.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Your Sister is so, so, but i'faith you have twenty beauties to one of hers: methinks your Eyes are—but 'tis no matter, I dare not look upon 'em, if you prove hard hearted like your Sister.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Try me Sir, I hope you'l find me other wise.—

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Then a woman I would not, for 'tis their glory to frown on all; but could I be so happy, to gain a place within you soft affection, how would I strive to make me worthy of you.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: You are already,—heigh ho—

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Come sigh no more, I find you love me dearly.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: But will you not betray me? tell my Sister, and lay me open to her Scorn and Laughter?

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Not I by Heav'n, Pox I'll be hang'd and damn'd first.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Nor forsake me?

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Give me your hand, I am yours then; to morrow I will pretend a sickness, and send for you as a most learn'd Physitian: but be secret.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: As a Physitian ought, I'll warrant you.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: That done—but tell no body.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Pox take me if I do.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: And the Room clear'd—but be silent as you respect my Honour.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Fear not, I have more respect to a Ladies honour than so.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: I'll leave the rest to you: you are wise enough to manage Love affairs. Farewell.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: If I fail, may I never have such fair Assignations again: a Quaker and a Doctor? two excellent disguises to get Maiden-heads in; I am Ravish'd, that's certain; a Quaker and a Doctor? oh excellent!

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Th' Excuse is fair, and sounds like reall Truth; but what he prompts me to's so full of dangerous hazards, I fear to undertake it.—Wait in the Garden Mask'd [Reads. and in your Night-gown, and there expect th'event.— What should it mean? What Plot's in action now? Why should I ask that question, or doubt the firmness of it, when Love is chief Conductor? I will venture it, attend the hour, and wish to see th' Event: Love cannot injure Love, nor dare it think on any cruell thought; or if it dare, I will be arm'd against it.

div.stage: Enter as in discourse Sir Arthur Twilight and Sir Generall Amorous.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Contentious Surlys Wife?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: The same Sir.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: In my Garden?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Yes Sir, for Love has made her look for such a shift to free her from his Tyrannous Jealousy, and I chose this course before any other, not only to make us sport, but to reap my wish'd for Ends.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: A pretty and most pleasant project! who would not strain a point of Neighbourhood for such a quaint device? I'll go fetch her presently.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: How the Old villain joys in Villany.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Sir Generall, Sir Generall, a rare Device.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: What yet again? what Strategem have you now?

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: The best that ever was, I'll fetch my Wife's Gown which you may put upon Petulant Easy, that if he chance to meet her, he may not have the least suspect but take her for Eudoria.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: That I have done already, and so disguis'd and mask'd she waits you in the Garden.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: I'll fetch her presently, Lord, Lord, how it pleases me to think upon Contentious, poor man ha, ha, ha, I laugh to think how he will rave, when he shall miss his Wife, a Cuckold, o law a Cuckold! ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Now nothing sure can cross me, this night I shall enjoy Eudoria and revell in the pleasures of her Love, what will Sir Arthur say when he shall miss his Wife? he can but vex or perhaps hang himself, let him do either, all's one to me so I but enjoy his Wife.

div.stage: Enter Arthur, bringing in Eudoria in a Night-gown Mask'd.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p:
I have her, I fack Sir Generall I have; poor soul how she shakes, come, come Madam fear nothing, Sir Generall is a pleasant Wag, he is indeed a very pleasant Wag; and I dare say loves you with his heart, truely he does, Lord lord, how she
transports me! I am in love with her too, and methinks I could—but let that alone,—let that alone.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Pardon me Madam, the great desire I had to see you before I went from London, made me so importunate.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: You are not, indeed you are not, what importunate? no, no, no, Sir Generall loves to Complement, he does indeed, but come let's goe, I fack we must drink before we part.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Nay, now the Rascall's troublesome.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Come Mr. Amorous, what at a stand? come follow me, I'll lead you to a Glass of the best Tent in London, I will indeed, a glass of that, and half a dozen Eggs will make me as vigorous as a Lover of Eighteen, it will indeed.

sp.speaker: Eme.
sp.p: Where is Sir Arthur?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Gone out, but where, I know not.

sp.speaker: Eme.
sp.p: If he stay abroad but long enough 'tis well.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Pray Sister what do you intend to doe with Sir Geoffry?

sp.speaker: Emel.
sp.p: What? make an Ass of him. I'll help his zeal to a Mistriss, and fit him to a hair I'll warrant him.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Why, will you let him in?

sp.speaker: Emel.
sp.p: Yes, and conduct him to our Masking Room, where by the help of the Trap-doors I doubt not to effect what I desire: I have already prepared our Scullion, who when the Candle is out, shall enter for a woman and perform my part, he is shaved on purpose, and I do not fear but he will banter him bravely.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: He comes to me to morrow, if the affront you put upon him dash not all his hopes.

sp.speaker: Emel.
sp.p: That you must salve again, by railing at me for the injury I did to Sir Geoffry; for his part he is so good natur'd hee'l soon believe you.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: I would not lose the Opportunity for all my hopes of marriage.

sp.speaker: Emel.
sp.p: Sister it grows late, within this half hour I expect him.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Let us part then. Pray Heaven the Lecher comes.

sp.speaker: Emel.
sp.p: Nothing more sure, be near to see th' event.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: I'll warrant you.

div.head: SCENE A Tavern.
div.stage: Enter Sir General Amorous, and Sir Arthur Twilight, Leading Eudoria mask'd.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Come, come, Madam, you are so melancholy, so all a mort: Sir General, pray come and comfort the Lady.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Sir Arthur, I must beg you to officiate my place for a minute, whilest I go down and dispatch a little business.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Blest Opportunity! she is right I'll warrant her, or else she would not leave her Husband to run away with a Gallant, but it is common i'fack, very common. Come Lady let us sitdown together, you look so like my Wife that I could eat you, nay come, this coyness not becomes you.— [Eudoria sits at a distance. Nearer a little, nearer yet, let me, let me feel your hand; a delicate soft moist palm upon my word; very good symptoms indeed, let me see, good breasts too, Lord, Lord, how she charms me! nearer yet dear Lady, she is a delicate Creature, and has all the symptoms of a Miss about her. Pray Madam off with your mask, that base injurious thing— [Eudoria points to the Candle.] Ha! put out the Candle? I understand her meaning, i'fack I do. [Puts out the Candle. Eudoria steals out. Now Madam I have perform'd your orders, I hope you will allow me the honour of your Lip, your cherry Lip, your rosie Cheeks, your dainty Teeth, your soft moist Palm, but here's enough of that; come dear Lady let us hug one another; nay you shall not deny me, you know I know you, come little Wag, you know I do; what, keep from your friend and servant? nay, nay, if you are run into a corner I'll after you, i'faith I will.

div.stage: [Gropes to find her out, and falls over the stooles.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: Thus far I have dog'd Sir General, and was inform'd below, he and a Lady were above together, which if I find, and see apparent falshood in the man I love, I'll study for revenge, and in his death blot out my shame for ever.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p:
Madam, dear Madam, nay now you are unkind, indeed you are Lady, dear Lady. Gropes about, at length seizes Petulant Easy.
Ha, have I caught you Wag, ha? come, come, let us solace our selves, let us enjoy one another, come, come, I am ready again, I am indeed, the fall did not hinder much.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: What are you Sir?

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: A man, a man, a vigourous old man i'fack, come, come,—

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: You are mistaken in the woman sure.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: No but I am not, these soft moist hands are a good sign, i'faith they are.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: A sign of what Sir?

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: A stirring, brisk, airy, lively, sprightly woman; one that will kiss and hug, and hug and kiss, and kiss and hug to a miracle i'faith.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: Nay if you are rude I'll leave you.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: But you shall not, come, come, be pliant, Sir Amorous will be here presently, and then our sport is spoil'd, come, come, dear Lady.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Shift for your self, or you're undone for ever, Contentious Surly is below, in such a rage, as if the Spanish Devil Jealousy were dancing in his eyes; he swears he dog'd you hither, and nothing can satisfie him but search the house he must.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Surly below? O law, what's to be done now?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Here, here, into this Closet, if he should chance to take you twill be but as a jeast.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Make hast, make hast, would it were over once.

div.stage: Easy and Sir Arthur enter into the Closet, the Drawer locks the door and Exit.
Enter Contentious Surly with a Light.

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p:
O damn'd Creature! can nothing keep her honest? [Looks about the Stage. Not here, the jilting Quean has tricks, and shifts her shape as often as a Witch, she's here for certain, and must not scape my Inquisition. [Breaks open the Closet.
Ha! have I found you Madam? and you lecherous Sir? come out ye pair ofsinners, and let the world be witness of my shame.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: What shame, to be in a Closet with an old man alone? is that your wonder Sir? nay with such an old man as has nothing but desire about him.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Not I by Heaven, I am an Eunuch Sir.

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: You are a Devil Sir, a Goatish Devil; and were it not for the respect I have to your black souls, which I would not take so unprepared, I'de send you both to Hell immediately.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: Do hasty Husband, I dare you do your utmost; strike, 'tis a woman bids you, where is your fury now? if you have any I'll raise it to a pitch, and leave you in the height on't. Know I hate thee, and all thy surly humours, and will never be slave to a Jealous Husband more. Farewell, if you dare see the Monster, I will make you home to your Glass and view your self.

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: Brave, I am a Beast all over, a publick noted Beast, and she a Devil, howe're she shall not 'scape me.

sp.speaker: Arthur.
sp.p:
If this be the effects of whoring, I have done with it: pray Heaven Eudoria hear not of it.
Enter Drawer. Where is Sir General Amorous?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: He and the Lady you brought in just now took Coach together.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: The Lady, what Lady?—

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: The Lady in the Night-gown.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Was there a Lady besides Easy then?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Yes, a delicate sweet Creature, much like your Wife.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: How? my Wife, my Wife? by Heaven it may be so indeed! I have a strong suspicion for it, I shall run mad, mad, stark mad; my Wife, my Wife, my Wife, I am a Cuckold, I am, I am, I am indeed, a damn'd procuring Cuckold.

div.head: SCENE Sir Arthur's House.
div.stage: Enter Sir Geoffry Jolthead, like a Quaker.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: I am transformed, I am another Creature, and have the tone of the Brethren, pray Heaven I may have the success too, but not to be toss'd out of a Balcony: that is Emelia's Chamber, I find it by the Light, now to my sign, Hum, hum.

sp.speaker: Emel.
sp.p: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Thy Brother Zachariah, who desires to meet thee in the way of the Faithfull.

sp.speaker: Emel.
sp.p: I will descend, thy prefence is most gratefull.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Now for a night of pleasure, i'faith it will tast the sweeter, because we act like Brethren: Oh those dear debauch'd Brethren! how many merry nights they spend with a Go in, Increase, and Multiply.

sp.speaker: Emel.
sp.p: Enter Zachariah, thou hast a Sister's leave.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: And I will perform the part of a Holy Brother.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Eudoria, Wife Endoria I say, what out of doors at this time? where shall I seek this Gad-fly? why Wife I say: she's gone, she's gone, a pox of the Salutation Tavern, she's gone with Sir Amorous, I find she is, a Coach, a Coach, a Coach, a hundred pound for a Coach.

sp.speaker: Spy.
sp.p: That was Sir Arthur's voice, now to my posture. Confusion take me if e're I serve again.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Spy.
sp.p: One that resolves never to serve a Rambling man again.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: This is Spymell, I may learn something from him. [Aside. Did you serve a Rambling Master then?

sp.speaker: Spy.
sp.p: Yes a common Whoremaster? no longer agoe than this Evening he run away with a very Worthy Gentlemans Wife.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Ha! did he so, did he so, what Gentleman, friend?

sp.speaker: Spy.
sp.p: A very Worthy man indeed, one Sir Arthur Twilight.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Confusion! I am the Cuckold then—

sp.speaker: Spy.
sp.p: But were I he, I would—

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Spy.
sp.p: In some disguise search out the Lecherous goat, and damn 'em both together.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Ay, ay, but what disguise?

sp.speaker: Spy.
sp.p: They now are at the Rose, drinking, carrowsing, and in a height of Jollity; but would he goe guis'd like an old Fidler, and take his man in a strange habit with him, he might perhaps revenge, and keep himself from being made a Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: He might indeed, he shall about it streight; thanks honest Friend, he shall about it presently.

sp.speaker: Spy.
sp.p: This will be Mirth to Admiration: I could e'en hug my self to think upon the Credulous fool, I must not lose him though.
sp.l: The bliss of Life whilst Mars and Venus rules
Is to project for Wise-men, Cuckold Fools.

div.head: SCENE A Chamber.
div.stage: Sir Geoffry Jolthead and Emelia are discovered imbracing.

sp.speaker: Eme.
sp.p: Nay, you are too vigorous, Brother.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: My Zeal is hot, I am inflam'd, my Spirits are on fire.

sp.speaker: Eme.
sp.p: After our Ceremonies are perform'd, we will like holy Brethren meet and love together.
sp.l: First with this Powder I'll perfume your Face,
Then with this Band your tender Wrists Embrace.
Well scented thus with all your Vigour move,
Turn three times round, and then enjoy your Love.

div.stage: Blacks his Face, and ties his Hands behind him, then puts out the Candle and Exit.
Enter an Old man drest about the head like a Woman.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: I come, I come, I come, this is one of the prettiest devices in the whole Creation. Madam, Lady Emelia, what not answer me? Nay then i'faith have at you, I am old Dog at Buff; I could play at Blind-mans Buff naturally, ha, that was a shroad Mistake. Runs against something and breaks the string that bound his Hands. Why Lady, dear little Rogue; where are you, ha? there I touch'd you; faith have I got you, have I, have I? nay now I will make you kiss me, and hug me, and imbrace me, and O my dear little Rogue. Having caught the Old man, he Kisses and Embraces him till a Table with two Candles upon it rises. Bless me! what have I got here?

sp.speaker: Old man.
sp.p: Nothing but an Old man indeed Sir.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: An Old Devil are you not? begon Wizard or I'll make you Kicks the Old man off, returns again, and is let down under the Stage. O Devil, Devil, Devil! Whither am I going now? help, help, help.—

div.head: SCENE Covent Garden.
div.stage: Enter Sir Arthur Twilight with a Cymball, and Bramble with a Violin, both disguis'd.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Come Bramble, we shall find her anon I am sure on't.

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: Would we could Master, for I am half afraid to walk abroad so late.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: No danger, no danger Bramble: O that we could but find 'em, I would Roguefy my Amorous Gentleman, i'fack I would.
