div.stage: [Musick and a Noise of Singing as in the Streets.

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: Ha, the Roaring Boys are abroad Master, and if we stay here any longer we shall be kill'd for certain.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: They are coming indeed, they are near us now, what shall we doe Bramble? O here's honest Spywell.

sp.speaker: Spy.
sp.p: So so you're well disguis'd. Now, now Sir is your time; Sir Generall Amorous and your Wife are enteredthere, there in that publick Tavern, they've sent to see for Musick: now if you dare venture to pass amongst the Gang, I will conduct you to 'em.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: With all my heart, Oh I long to see 'em.

sp.speaker: Spy.
sp.p: Where taken for Musicians, you may stand unsuspected, and behold all their Transactions.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Make hast, make hast, O how I long to see 'em!

sp.speaker: Spy.
sp.p: Which you shall do, doubt not, and suffer for your Curiosity.
sp.l: Rais'd to a height, he from the top shall fly
To perish by his Rage and Iealousy.

div.trailer: The End of the Third Act.

div.head: ACT IV.
SCENE The Streets.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: I Am out again, thanks to my good fortune: if this be Love and Enjoyment, the Devil take it for me; 'twas twenty to one I had not broke my Neck when I fell into the Cellar, my Mistress Emelia was a little civill I confess to leave a Light below, otherwise I might have slept amongst the hogsheads: I have lost all my stomach to Womans flesh, and shall never have a good opinion of the Sex as long as I live again.

sp.speaker: Twif.
sp.p:
My Lord your servant, I vow I am extream glad to see you, your Honourable Cousins are all in good health, and
every thing goes extraordinarily well indeed. I just now came from France, and truely every thing there is in a very good posture: his most Christian Majesty would fain have laid his Commands upon me to have been his Generalissimo, but I hearing the English Drums beat up for Volunteers, came to pay my Respects to my very good Friend and Cousin, and to serve under the noble Banner of England.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: What a Pox is the meaning of this?

sp.speaker: Twif.
sp.p: My Lord I cannot but commend your meen and garb, upon my honour you are all over very charming, and look like one of the honourable family of the Soft-heads, I hope my Cousin Richard, and his extraordinary obliging friend Thomas are in perfect health.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Yea Sir. What a pox ails he?

sp.speaker: Twif.
sp.p: And my Lady Grace, and Madam Pru, and that extream obliging Lady Madam Text, I vow I long to see e'm, but my extraordinary business in Town, has hindred me from their Society. Why I'll tell you Cousin, I am just now going to serenade Madam Emelia, upon my honour she's fort obleigant.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: She is all abomination, and musick is the wind-pipe of Lucifer.

sp.speaker: Twif.
sp.p: But mark you Cousin, mine is no wind musick, first, here is a Tin Pot, which besides its excellent vertues of making a delicious, sweet, charming, melodious sound, serves at a shift to drink out of; then here is an Extinguisher, and here a Drumstick, all which meeting together, make an excellent harmony; you shall hear it Cousin.

div.stage: [Plays upon his Pot, and sings ridiculously.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Avant Satan, these are not the Devices of the Brethren, be-gone with your Galemofry of Noises, or I shall rebuke thee, mark you?

sp.speaker: Twif.
sp.p: How do you like the musick, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Be gone I say, you disturb the ears of the faithfull.

sp.speaker: Twif.
sp.p: But Cousin.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: I will not hear thee, vanish thou Hocus Pelabrius, or look you, thus I will force you.

sp.speaker: Twif.
sp.p: But my Lord, nay Cousin, my Lord, I say—

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: She has scap'd my rage again, and unless she be at home I know not where to seek her.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: What lewd disturber is that?

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: 'Sdeath hold thy tongue.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: I say thou hast evil intentions, and designest to rob the house of my friend.

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: Thy friend! who art thou?

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: A faithfull Brother, by Name Geoffrius, Zacharias Iolt.

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: Strange! I should know that voice, are you Sir Geoffry?

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Yea, I am the man, now tell me, who art thou?

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: My name's Contentious Surly.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: The Devil it is? what my good Friend and Landlord? i'faith I have been frolicking of it to night, I have i'faith: and how goes squares with thee, ha boy?

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: Faith cross, extreamly cross, my Wife has given me two slips for a Teaster, and is run the Devil knows whither.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: That's fine i'faith; would I could meet her, she kisses smartly, and has the Town ways to a hair i'faith. [Aside. Is she not at home?

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: That's all the hope remains.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Let's knock and enter, if they refuse break open the doors.

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: Agreed.

div.stage: Surly knocks a good while, at length breaks open the doors.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: That's well said •••• h enter and search, we shall find her in a corner.

div.head: SCENE A Tavern.
div.stage: Enter Sir General Amorous, Eudoria and Spywell.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Is all prepar'd?

sp.speaker: Spy.
sp.p: All's in a readiness to entertain Sir Arthur.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p:
Then let in the Masquerading Ladies, and bid the Fidlers approach. [Exit Spywell.
Come Madam, on with your Mask, to night we will enjoy our loves without disturbance, and smile upon the Jealous Fool thy Husband, whose curiosity shall lead him to his ruine.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: I fear hee'l know me.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Let him, he shall not dare to touch you, nor gaze upon you with the eyes of anger: to animate his rage chuse him out to Dance with you, I have ordered another to make choice of Bramble, who will also at the appointed time leave him with his Credulous Master, and both shall be convey'd so great a distance from us, that scarce his cries shall enter to disturb our joys.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: I'm too hard hearted to a Jealous Husband.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Would you be kind to him and ruine me? would you destroy me on the virge of bliss, or kill what you have made? I should not urge had you content at home, but being rob'd of such a weighty blessing, and made a starveling to the joys of Wedlock, I come with real and hearty zeals, to give you those pleasures his Age and Impotence deny'd.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: I'm too far entred now to make retreat without the loss of Honour, I must be yours for ever; but use me kindly, lest the strange surprize should kill my blooming hopes.

div.stage: Enter Spywell with Fidlers and Ladies, amongst whom are Sir Arthur, Bramble and Petulant Easy disguis'd, all the men and women are mask'd but the Fidlers.

sp.speaker: Spy.
sp.p: Come, Come Gentlemen, strike up, and let the musick of the Sphears speak loud, whilest they employ their feet in Dancing Measures.

div.stage: Eudoria and a Lady go to take out Sir Arthur and Bramble, who deny a great while, but at length yield and join with them. A Dance. All Dance off but Sir Arthur, Spywell, Bramble, and Easy, who all continue dancing but Easy.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: 'Tis she, I know it; perfidious man you shall not 'scape my fury, must I be thus rewarded for my Favours, and not study a requital? rise up black revenge, and teach me to be cruel; teach me to act as bloody Nero did, that in my height of love and vengeance I may damn both, both their black souls together.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Ha! gone?

sp.speaker: Spy.
sp.p: Yes, yes Sir, come hither, both direct your eyes that way, and there behold what would confound a man not arm'd with so much reason—What see you Sir?

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Nothing.

sp.speaker: Spy.
sp.p: Nor you?

sp.speaker: Bram.
sp.p: Not I by Iove.

sp.speaker: Spy.
sp.p: Look, look, I see 'em kissing, there, there, like wanton Turtles they're billing both together.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Where, where?

sp.speaker: Spy.
sp.p: There, there. Stamps, Sir Arthur and Bramble are let down under the Stage, they cry help. Now you are safe enough, and secur'd from all disturbance; and Sir General Amorous may now in peace enjoy the fair Eudoriae; all the reward I hope for is success. Projecting is my genuine Mistress, and in my brain I lodge the soft Belov'd, and treat her minutely with pleasing Embryo's, which by the moderate heat of smooth desires, are lull'd into perfections, which at once create and give me pleasures.
sp.l: These harmless plots perhaps may seem unjust,
But when such loads you adde to one man's trust,
Blame not projections if they onely prove
A Servants care t'obtain a Masters love.

div.head: SCENE A Bed-chamber.
div.stage: Sir General Amorous and Eudoria are discovered sitting by the Bed side.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Come blush no more, I am thy Husband now, and with a Passion more innate then his, I will exhilirate thy soul, and lead thy senses in a Sea of pleasures, where, arm in arm, wee'l wanton 'twixt the Waves, and every minute find new pastimes out, revel in joys of uncontroul'd delights, and dwell for ever in this bright Elyzium.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: You've nam'd a word-which bates me of my hopes, and dashes all those thoughts I just now dream't of.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: It shall be banish'd quite, or like a foyle stand still to heighten pleasure, what was't Eudoria?

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Nothing but Husband Sir: that very word curbs all my joys, and prompts me to a sense, that all's imaginary.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: What frown of fate can take you from my bosome, or rob me of the treasure I embrace?

sp.speaker: Spy.
sp.p: Sir I have done the work.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Is he safe?

sp.speaker: Spy.
sp.p: As a thief in a mill, ne'r fear it; but here's one danger yet unconquer'd, the jealous Easy, who (it seems mistrusting you were here) came as a Masquerader, and after the dance, followed you and Eudoria, and had doubtless surpriz'd you here, but that the Drawer by meer force kept her back.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: What, must I be prevented then?

sp.speaker: Spy.
sp.p: Sir you had best go and appease her rage, perhaps she'l hear your reasons.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: I will, but with a curse able enough to damn her.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: Where's this unconstant man, and this false treacherous woman? Oh let my anger meet 'em both, and in one breath confound 'em.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: What's this?

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: Nothing lascivious Lady but the force of love, and you if you had any grace might think it so, how durst you look upon that faithless man, or entertain the least thoughts of such a loose desire, and not tremble? I am all fury, and could shoot such killing glances on you, which would (but you're so practis'd in the art already) reduce you to a heap of earth again. Base treacherous woman!

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: I understand you not.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: Then I • ll be plainer, you are a—

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Woman, and so are you, both married women too, and love Sir General both.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: Your Husband shall know all.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: So shall Contentious too: but talk is frivolous, and may perhaps hinder a new appointment. Farewell.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: Brave! she has impudence enough to stock the Sex in general. How shall I be reveng'd? I'll haste to find Sir Arthur, tell him her crimes, and urge him to revenge.
sp.l: Thus to be slighted, now I all have giv'n,
Calls for confusion, and revenge from Heav'n.

div.head: SCENE The Streets.
div.stage: Enter Contentious Surly, and Sir Geoffry Jolt.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Nay, nay, be patient man, what! fret for the loss of a woman? one that loves pleasure? pox on her let her go, let her go, you and I will to a Bawdy house, and there solace our selves, ha? shall we boy, ha?

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: No Sir.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: What not to a Bawdy house? let's to a Tavern then, drink and be drunk, and kiss every woman we meet.

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: I am not given to the Flesh so much Sir.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Nor I neither, but I do it in revenge, I will lye with twenty women successively, and all to be reveng'd of one; but thou hast a Wife.

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: Damnation seize her, why should I of all the world be made so wretched? why should my fate be so severe, so cruel? No one can see I am a Cuckold, but I know I am, there, there's the plague on't.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I cannot sleep to night for thinking on Sir Geoffry, oh how I long to see him! the great affront my Sister put upon him, I fear will keep him from me, which makes me venture at this unseasonable hour to find him out, and wheadle him into a strange belief of my affection: ha!—yonder he is, now to be taken notice of.

div.stage: [Puts on her mask, and passes over the Stage.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Ha! are you there, are you there i'faith? blest Moonshine! I have discovered a Lady, a Night-walker upon my life. I'll after her.

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: How shall I find her out? which way contrive to revel in revenge? Sir General Amorous is the man that wrongs me, and on him I'll pour my indignation: but how the Devil came Sir Arthur and she lock'd up in the Closet together? how? why she's common and fond of all the world: he, he shall suffer too, but in a different way, the one shall die, and the other be made as monstrous as I am.

div.stage: Enter Flora mask'd, Sir Geoffry following, seizes her.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Nay little Rogue, i'faith you shall not 'scape me; 'twould be unkindly done to let you go alone, so early in the morning too, come, come, let me see you home to your lodging little Wag.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: I beg your pardon Sir, I do not use it.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: What! not your lodging Rogue? let's to a Tavern then, where wee'l drink and be so merry, so jocost and pleasant, and kiss and hug, and love one another.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Who are you Sir?

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: A Country Magistrate, Lady, one that doats upon womans Flesh, a very Cully, believe me Madam.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: You'l pawn me Sir.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Not I by Iove, what, pawn a pretty Lady? that were unkind indeed; I may be frolicksome or so, but i'faith I will not pawn you.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I dare not venture to a Tavern Sir.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Let's to thy Lodging then, all's one to me; here, here's the tempting Angels, all this for a nights lodging I Gad: now I am all vigor, and shall I, hah? little Rogue shall I?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: If you'l be kind.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: As a Lover can be, thou shalt have Gloves, and Fans, and Muffs, and Ribbands, and—

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: A Monky too.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Yes, yes, a great Baboon, come, come, let's go.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: You have such taking ways.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: And so have you i'faith. Here's one of my twenty that's certain.

div.head: SCENE Covent Garden.
div.stage: Enter two Sedan-men bringing Sir Arthur Twilight in Bramble's cloaths, and Bramble in Sir Arthur's cloaths, bound and gag'd in a Sedan.

sp.speaker: 1. Sed.
sp.p: Pox on 'em, they're cursed heavy.

sp.speaker: 2. Sed.
sp.p: Full of sin, full of sin Brother; but let's set 'em down here in the Piazza's, and go and take a cherishing cup this morning.

sp.speaker: 1. Sed.
sp.p: Agreed, but I am afraid it is too early.

sp.speaker: 2. Sed.
sp.p: No, no, no, they are up at the King's-head I'll warrant you.

div.stage: Sir Arthur and Bramble come out of the Sedan.

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: Gone from thence too? She is a Necromancer that's certain, and has a Legion of Devils to attend her. What have we here, Sir Arthur Twilight, and his Honourable servant Bramble? they are in a pretty Posture too, and stand seasonably for a beating, which that old Lecher shall not want; this for Bellowing the name Cuckold in my Ears,—and all these for being lock'd up with my Wife. And so farewell Sir.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: O that I could but find Sir Arthur now to tell him all the story of his Wife, and pour into his Ears the strongest Venome that ever Poysoned man; and here he is, most happy opportunity. I'm sorry Sir, that I should be the Messenger of such ill news, as I am forc'd to tell you; but when a man is Married to a Wife, false and unconstant, one all desires, and greedy after Pleasures, one that shall force a man to her Embraces, and hug him with a Zeal—what, not answer me? [Bramble makes a Noise. Alas Poor man, this was Eudorias Plot, her loose Contrivance, is't not enough to wrong her Husbands Bed, but she must serve him so, make him the Scoff, and Scorn of all the World?—

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: Thank you Madam, this is the first kindness I ever received of a Woman in my life.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: Are you not Sir Arthur then?

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: No, but I am his Man, and that's as good.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: Where is your Master?

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p:
There stands the Worshipfull Gentleman, you may be kind and release him if you please: Easy goes and unbinds Sir Arthur.
this is the fruits of Fidling and Horn-hunting with a Pox, but if ever you take me in a Disguise again, I'll give you leave to hang me. Pox of Surlys blows,
they were very unwelcome to me because they were meant to my Master.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Madam, I can but thank you for my liberty: it was a severe Torment, it was indeed.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: But who transform'd you thus?

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: I'faith I know not.

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: Two Devils I think, they were disguis'd I'm sure.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: Were I so injur'd, nothing should keep me from Revenge.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Ha! what said you there, Revenge? I'fack I long to be reveng'd, but how?

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: The Cure must needs be dangerous, when the Disease rages with so much violence; you are not unsensible you are a Cuckold?

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Ha?

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: Wonder not at it, for you're so that's certain, I saw 'em both folded like Twins together, destilling Kisses, intermixing Glances, and with a Rapture unexpressible, dissolve into a showre.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: A Cuckold?

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: I heard her boast, and glory in his Love, repeat the numbers of his Obligations, count o're his Charms in such a wanton Dialect, as would almost intice a Saint to sin.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: A Cuckold, O Confusion!

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: Then being tyr'd and glutted with Excess, repeat the pleasures of her stoln Delights, whilst her Lascivious Ears suck'd in the sound, that every Sense might have an equall share.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: No more, no more, no more. Death no more.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: Sometimes she'd with a scornfull smile call on your name, and say Alas poor Sir Arthur, poor decrepit Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Cuckold again! no more, no more, sweet Lady have you done?

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: If it offend I have.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Why, do you think it pleases, a Cuckold, a horrid, nay a known Cuckold too? I will be reveng'd that's certain, nay swindginly reveng'd, a Cuckold? O horrid! come along Bramble.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p:
He's fir'd, and nothing sure can quench him, but the removall of his Wife Eudoria; then I shall enjoy his Love in Peace, and fear no other Rivall; yet there's one danger still,
a Jealous Husband, he shall be remov'd too, they are not fit to live who hourly strive to curb a Womans Joys, I will about it presently.

div.stage: Enter Twiford talking to two Link-boys.

sp.speaker: Twif.
sp.p: Truly every thing is very considerably well, and my Honourable Lord is in a delicate pleasing humour, and my Lady is—but as I was telling you my Lords, about the Play. I just now came from the Kings house, and truly every thing is very considerably well: and truly I doubt not but to make a considerable advantage of the Comedy; for I have very considerably insinuated my self into the opinion of the Leading Wits,—and I have their— [The Link-boys sneak off. promise for applause, for indeed my Lord they know me for a Wit, and were extraordinarily pleas'd with my Heroick Poem call'd The Man of New-Market, and so forth; but let that pass, my Lords I see you do not regard me, and sleep is very necessary for a Poet, and so good night my Lords.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: I am hem'd about on all sides, and cannot scape the Watch, what shall I do for shelter till the Day breaks or the Clutches of the Parish are retir'd, ha! what's there, a Sedan, and no body near it?[A Noise as of the Watch. Hark! the Watch are coming, I'll enter there and secure my self,— [Noise again. There's a man in it, what shall I do now.— [Noise again. I must enter were he a Devil, till the Watch is past.

div.stage: [Enters into the Sedan and shuts the door.

sp.speaker: 2. Sed.
sp.p: Pox on't, there's no Drink to be got, I think 'tis scarce two.

sp.speaker: 1. Sed.
sp.p: Let it be scarce one an't will, I care not, for I am devilish dry.

sp.speaker: 2. Sed.
sp.p: So am I too, but come, let us up with our load, by that time we have drop't them in the Fields it will be day.

div.stage: Enter Contentious Surly, Constable and Watchmen.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Stand, who goes there?

sp.speaker: 1. Sed.
sp.p: Friends.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Who have you in your Sedan?

sp.speaker: 1. Sed.
sp.p: No body, Mr. Constable.

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: Search, search the Sedan, Mr. Constable, 'tis twenty to one but some Night-walking Lady or other is in it.

sp.speaker: Sed. in.
sp.p: With all our hearts, there it is, search your Eyes out.

div.stage: Whilst they are opening the Sedan, the men sneak away. The Sedan being opened discovers Twiford embracing Easy.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: What so close together? come out, come out I pray.

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: Death my Wife! and with a Mad-man too, this is insufferable; I am glad I have found your Ladiship, would your Honour be conducted home in a Sedan? you shall be Sedan'd with a pox. Mr. Constable pray give me leave to secure this Lady, upon my word she shall appear at the first summons.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Do you know her Sir?

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: Too well, I wish I did not, she is my Wife.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: You have Liberty.

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: Come Minion will you walk? I'll secure you for gadding I'll warrant you.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Stay, stay, what are you?

sp.speaker: Twif.
sp.p: Truly my Honourable Lord is very well, and as I told you the Play will take.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: What's all this to me? Who are you I say?

sp.speaker: Twif.
sp.p: As I was saying, Lewis the 14th. is a brave Prince, and a very considerable Souldier; why look you Coz, this Ring was given me by Madam Buly, she is a very Honourable Lady, and takes much pains for the Publick.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Tell not me of Publicks, but give me an account, what are you?

sp.speaker: Twif.
sp.p: Very considerably well indeed, and every thing is in a very good method, and—

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Watchmen away with him, he is a suspicious Person.

sp.speaker: Twif.
sp.p: Truly Cousin I know nothing of the matter.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: What matter?

sp.speaker: Twif.
sp.p:
The very great Affairs of State, and Matters now in
Question are that the People of Stetin are a very Honourable People, and deserve to be a—

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I care not what they deserve to be, who are you? whence came you? and whither are you going?

sp.speaker: Twif.
sp.p: Truly my Lord you are very obliging, but I know nothing of the matter, but my Lord I'll tell you, his Honour— I must beg your pardon Cousin, the good Lord Iohn is just now come to town, and it will be accounted a great piece of rudeness to be absent, and be so considerably well, your Servant Cousin.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: After him there and seize upon him, I will know what he is before he get his liberty.

div.head: SCENE A Bed-Chamber.
div.stage: A Table with two Candles and some Books upon it set upon the Stage. Enter Sir Geoffry Jolt and Flora Mask'd.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Now you are kind indeed, I'faith you are; come Lady let us prepare, let us undress, O how I long to be in Bed dear Lady!

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Do you begin Sir, I'll but go in and dress my Head, and wait upon you presently.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Pretty Rogue, an excellent Lodging this, this is no Mercenary Mistress. Lord, Lord, the Town Gallants are such conceited Animals, such Fops Alamode, they think no body has the happiness of Enjoying their Ladies but themselves. What's here, a Study? Aristotles Problems, excellent, and here Leschole de Files, a pretty French book; and here Annotations upon Aretines Postures, three Excellent Books for a Ladies Chamber; but I am tardy, I stay too long, I should have been in bed half an hour agoe; O for a week of Nights in One, that I might reap a Hecatoomb of Pleasures; who the Devil would marry and run the danger of being made a Cuckold, when he may live so freely? Come Lady, I am almost unready now, I am almost prepar'd, and could methinks—

sp.speaker: Emel.
sp.p: Good Morrow sweet Sir Geoffry.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Good Morrow credulous Sir Geoffry.

sp.speaker: Emel.
sp.p: How did you like the Lady in the Mask?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Was she not very charming, all Ayre and Conversation?

sp.speaker: Emel.
sp.p: Had she not a sprightly way of Courtship? did she not work you to a height with Art?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Did she not sigh, and swear she doated on you? long'd to betray her Honour to your Worship?

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Hold Syrens hold, you've said enough already.

sp.speaker: Emel.
sp.p: Not to a man of Learning, a Country Magistrate, one that would keep his Mistress like a Lady, present her daily with some Toy or other, as Muffs.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Fans.

sp.speaker: Emel.
sp.p: Gloves.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Ribbands.

sp.speaker: Emel.
sp.p: Neck-laces.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Dogs.

sp.speaker: Emel.
sp.p: Monkeys.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: And above all, an Over-grown Baboon, just such another as your hasty self.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Peace I say, or by my Authority I will disturb the House, raise all the Servants, fright the Watch, amaze the Neighbours, and bring a Scandal on you both for ever.

sp.speaker: Emel.
sp.p: Do, and we'll declare your Actions.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Relate your Course of life.

sp.speaker: Emel.
sp.p: Defame your Honour.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Scandal your Learning.

sp.speaker: Emel.
sp.p: And make your Name an Antidote, against the pleasingest Thoughts, the best desires that ever Woman had.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Have you done? have you done now? ye Pair of she Devils.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Yes, will you be pleas'd to walk Sir?

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Any where out of your Companies Ladies: may desire and the want of what you slight so now pursue you ever.

sp.speaker: Emel.
sp.p: Is he gone?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Yes, with an intent never to come again I • ll warrant him.

sp.speaker: Emel.
sp.p: Then let's to Bed.
sp.l: Imperfect Pleasures whilst in View they move,
Are the Ingenious Toyls of hasty Love.

div.trailer: The End of the Fourth Act.

div.head: SCENE The Streets.
div.stage: Enter Sir Generall Amorous, Eudoria and Spywell.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: PRay Heaven we reach the House before Sir Arthur, or else my Shame will kill me.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: This is the most dangerous Adventure Love e're thought on, and will I fear end in our ruins; for 'tis impossible t' anticipate his hast.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Fancy not storms before you see 'em rising: I am resolv'd either to save my Honour by this means, or meet my ruin quickly. [Goes to the Door and unlocks it.] Thus far I'm safe, and make no question now but to succeed, farewell. Some two hours hence I shall be glad to see you.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: What dogged Planet Reign'd at my Nativity! Saturn sure was Lord of the Ascendant; I could not else be cross'd as I have been: twice most willingly she gave Consent I should enjoy her Love, and still that Devil Jealousy frustrated all my hopes; which like a man drove by one wave ashore, is by another hurried back again. To love, and not enjoy is but to gaze upon Delicious meat, and have no pow'r to touch it; I must goe on. Within this two hours I shall be glad to see you? that, that alone, had I not had sufficient Proof before, would have confirm'd an Angel.
sp.l: On then to Bliss which we'll in private meet,
Where troubles past shall make it tast more sweet.

div.stage: Enter Sir Arthur Twilight and Bramble.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: I am out of Breath with running, a pox of Matrimony if this be the fruits on't, was ever Gentleman made a Cuckold before?

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, especially Citizens; 'tis an Hereditary possession belonging to the Court of Aldermen, and scarce one scapes it, if their. Wives are either Young or Handsome.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: I would mine had been neither, I would she had not been a Woman, rather than I should thus be made a Cuckold; but 'tis done, 'tis done, I am all over Horns that's certain, and shall be counted a greater Monster than the Elephant.

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: 'Tis something severe indeed, but the best is, you are not the first Citizen that has had his Wife run away with a Courtier.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Am I not Sirrah ha? you make a mock of it, do you?

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: No Sir no, I am in earnest.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Are you so Villain, are you so? but on, on, knock at the Door, I long to be fully satisfied.

div.stage: Enter Eudoria above in her Night-gown.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: What's that to you?

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Who are you?

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: A Friend, a Friend, one that should be Master of this House.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Who, my Dear Husband? my kind Sir Arthur? where have you been to Night?

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Ha! where have I been to Night? rather Lady where have you been to Night?

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Here, here in my Chamber, rob'd of the Blessing of your sweet society, it was unkindly done.—

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: It was indeed to run away from your Husband: but come, come, no more of that, open the Door Lady.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: I'll fly to do it, I am overjoy'd to see you.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: What is the meaning of this? I'faith I know not what to think on't.

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: Nor I neither, I am sure she was at the Tavern.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: But how came she home then? how in her Chamber undrest, ha?

sp.speaker: Bramb.
Arth.
sp.p: It is impossible, he went to the Salutation Tavern I am sure, I saw him, spoak to him, and drank with him there.

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p:
All this may be, and yet he be in Bed with your Wife; to know which I'll go into the Street, some two or
three doors from the House, and cry, fire, fire, then go to your Back door and watch that, whilst you your self watch this.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: This will do, this will do, i'fack haste and about it streight.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: O my dear Husband! where have you been to Night? all night abroad at Taverns? rob me of my Garments and then run away from me? Alas is this seemly, for a man of your Credit? your Age? and Affection to your Wife?

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: This is fine i'faith, miraculously fine. [Aside.] Was not I at home? call'd you like a Porter? stood under your Window unregarded, was almost mad with fury, and all this but last night, ha?

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Yes Sir, the harmless sleep you broke, and my answer to you would have witness'd it, if you had had the Patience to have stay'd one minute longer: but your so suddain retreat made me imagine you were gone with Sir Generall Amorous that common Debauche: keep him not company Dear, he is enough to ruine twenty Aldermen.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Hey day! this is fine indeed: it is impossible she shou'd be honest; and yet she has not the looks of a Sinner neither.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Ha Fire! I am undone for ever then.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Ha Fire! I'll watch this Door for that trick.

div.stage: Stands with his back against the door, Bramble within, fire, fire, &c.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Dear Husband let's go in and remove the Goods, we shall be lost for ever else.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Not I by Heav'n, I'll stand here till to Morrow first.

div.stage: Enter Sir Generall Amorous and Spywell.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: From whence this Dismall noise?

sp.speaker: Spyw.
sp.p: I know not Sir.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: See it has rais'd my Worthy Landlord and his Wife. Where is the Fire Sir?

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Nay I know not.—Hey day, hey day, stranger and stranger still.—

div.stage: Enter Contentious Surly in a Night-gown.

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: Good morrow Sir Arthur, you are Alarm'd by the Noise I see.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Not much Mr. Surly, I am proof against fire, I am a meer Salamander, and can live as well in the Flame as a Duck in the Water,—'sfoot I know not what to think of this— [Aside. Sir Generall, Sir Generall, you are a Wag, i'fack you are: what stay abroad all Night? come, tell me where were you, indeed you shall.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Troth Sir at a Tavern about a Mile from hence, where after the pleasures of Wine and Musick, I hoped to enjoy the Charming Easy, but was hindred by that Jealous Devil Surly.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Did he hinder you i'fack, did he come and take you?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Just in the nick by Heav'n.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: It was ten thousand pities, it was indeed, you lost a delicate Night on't, i'fack I am sorry for it: what, hindred of a Night?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: 'Twas my ill fortune Sir, but we shall meet again.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: I'll do my best to help you, I will indeed, where's your Man?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: There Sir.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: He looks clouded methinks.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: A little Sir, for want of Rest, he's a most faithfull Servant.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: A brave contriver I'll warrant him.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: How to get Drunk that's all: he roul'd last night just like a Bowl ill byas'd, and slept in every Corner.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: This is miraculous! I find I have abused my Wife all this while, and been Jealous for nothing; I am glad it is no worse though. O Villain! Monster that I was! how have I abus'd my self! He with Easy? and his man asleep in every Corner? this is strange indeed. [Aside. Pardon me Eudoria for leaving the Window so hastily, for my suddain Jealousy transfer'd me; I will say no more but this, I will not indeed, Dear Wife I suspected thee.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: How, did you suspect me?

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Talk no more of it, I did indeed, and am asham'd to own it; come, come, wee'l in, and every morning on my knees I'll beg a pardon from thee.

sp.speaker: Bram.
sp.p: He is not come out Sir.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: No matter, no matter, all's well again, I am Sir Arthur again, the brisk, bonny, and the merry Sir Arthur again, ha?

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: Where's the Fire Bramble?

sp.speaker: Bram.
sp.p: Fire? what Fire? was there any Fire?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: I heard 'em cry Fire.

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: And so did I.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: And I.

sp.speaker: Bram.
sp.p: Meer fancy, meer fancy, there is not a spark of fire in the whole City.

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: Then I'll to Bed again, good morrow Sir Arthur.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Nay Mr. Surly we will not part so, what, part with dry lips? out upon't, come, come, wee'l go into my House, and drink a Glass or two, and then part to our Beds; come Sir General.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Let it burn on, I have nothing to say to fire or women, they are both out of my Element, Wine, precious Wine I am for, the bloud of the Grape shall be my Mistriss: I have been damnably affronted by a couple of Jilting Queans already, and it will be hard to bring me into a third Praemunire. Where am I? O pretty near home, I find it, this 'tis to have good store of Wine in one's Head; a man reels to his Lodging so decently.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: Now I am lost, and hope is fled for ever, there's no way left t' accomplish my desire, nor how to bring about my wish'd for vengeance; I am a Pris'ner now, confin'd to one I hate above the World, and forc'd to love what I have cause to hate, the treacherous Amorous, but he is gone, fled to Eudoria's Bosome, and there is lodg'd a happy loving Guest.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Still, still in the reeling posture; what ne're leave me? ha, where am I? what, in my Landladies Chamber? now if I had not made an Oath to the contrary, I would venture to salute her: pox 'twas a foolish Oath, and ought not to be kept by a person of Honour, she kisses smartly, that's my comfort. By your leave Lady, I must have a touch with you.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: What mean you Sir?

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Nothing but honesty by my Sobriety, you have such a taking way with you, such a delicious turn of the lip, and so charming a breath, that I am almost ravish'd. [Offers to kiss Easy, she refuses. Nay believe me Lady 'tis a favour, and ought to be taken so, nay come, come Lady.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: Whither Sir?

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: To your Bed, it is a very convenient Utensil, and ought not to stand for a Cypher in a Ladies Chamber, these melting lips—Nay by my Honour, if you are coy I shall be a Devil, come, come, be as you should be, a delightfull yielding Female, I am sound I'll promise you, you may venture, dear Rogue—

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: Venture what Sir?

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: To add one horn more to your Husband's Forehead, come, come, I know you love to make him a Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: A Cuckold Sir?

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Yes, yes a Cuckold, I have made him one my self.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: In my sleep Lady, and there I thought you were so brisk, so airy, and so charming; and if you seem'd to be so then, I am sure you cannot chuse but be all pleasure now; come, dispatch.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: I shall be forc'd to cry a Rape if you provoke me thus.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
Easy.
sp.p: Help, help, a Rape, a Rape.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Pox what need you baule so loud, we shall disturb the Neighbours.

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: What means this Rudeness Sir?

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Nothing but Civility by my Honour: meer Passion by Iove, and who can be angry at a Passion?

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: It ill becomes you, especially in my House, Sir Geoffry.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Nay if you are angry I have done, Good morrow Landlord, I'll goe to bed and sleep, and Dream, and so forth.

sp.speaker: Easy.
Surly.
sp.p: He's drunk, he's drunk, and knows not what he does.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: Were it Sir Generall, or any other but this Goatish Geoffry, you would have entertained a strange Suspicion, and with a Jealousy as unrestrain'd as ever fury could invent, have hunted both to ruine, but now—

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: Enough, enough, let this content you, that I ne're before did entertain so fair a thought of Woman as now I do of thee: my foolish Jealousy still prompted me to think it was impossible you could be honest, or stand the Tryall of the least Temptation; but now I find thou hast a secret Virtue, which I will cherish ever: come let's retire.
sp.l: All Iealous Pangs you by this Act remove,
And now I shall renew Decaying Love.

div.head: SCENE Sir Arthur's House.
div.stage: Enter as in a Passion Sir Generall Amorous, followed by Sir Arthur Twilight and Eudoria.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Nay Sir Generall, i'faith I am sorry, I am indeed; what, leave your Friends house for a Trifle? nay sweet Sir Generall, I am not Jealous now, i'fack I am not; dear Wife go to him, perswade the Gentleman, win him again, I shall be distracted if he leave me, to him Dear—

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: I know 'tis but in vain.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Nay, nay try him, 'twas but a small affront to say I doubted him, or to be Jealous, was it? nay dear sweet Wife perswade him.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: I'll try my power Sir, but I fear th'event.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: That's well said, kiss him into friendship, hug him, do any thing to win him, (but lye with him) and I am satisfy'd.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Prepare a Banquet then to entertain him, and to it invite your Worthy friends; let it appear as costly as you can for such a little Warning, and I'll try if I can court him to it.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Do, do my little Rogue, and see how I will love you, the Night will come and then,—but 'tis no matter, thou knowest my meaning—

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Is he gone?

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Safe for an hour, I'll warrant him.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: How greedily he hunts his own Destruction, and with a Zeal as eager as our Loves, he strives to haste our Pleasures!

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Let us not lose that time by our neglect Heav'n has so kindly given.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: 'Twere sin to slip the opportunity. Fortune now courts us to a World of Pleasure, and should we slight the Blessing she has given, we might for ever starve and long for Joys, but never more approach 'em.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Where shall we goe?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: My Chamber is most safe; nay any where as you have chang'd his humour, he would mistrust his Eyes I'm sure before you.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Then let us goe, for fear we are prevented.

sp.speaker: Eme.
sp.p: This is a strange alteration, but yesterday my Father was as Jealous as a Husband without Eyes, and as Waspish as an ill pleas'd Bride; and now he is all Mirth and Jollity. Pray Heaven it last.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: So say I, for he just now proffered me a Husband: and if his Jealous Fitt should come again, I might chance to leade Apes in Hell; and that's a Curse too insufferable for me to bear.

sp.speaker: Eme.
sp.p: A Husband Flora! who was't?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: My degraded Magistrate, he tells me he is a man of Vigour, and loves me with an unspeakable flame.

sp.speaker: Eme.
sp.p: And can you fancy him?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Best of all, for he's not a Wit I can tell you, and those soft headed Husbands are the easiest Creatures to work upon; a Woman may doe what she pleases, keep a Gallant in Town, or maintain a comely Servant in the Country; who shall be as proud to effect my Will, as I desirous to command him.

sp.speaker: Eme.
sp.p: There's danger in 'em though, besides restraint of Liberty and Freedome, I hate to be mew'd up in a Country Castle, give me the Mall, or Grays-Inn Walks; and now and then a Play, where a Woman may receive as much Pleasure by gazing on the Gallants of the Town, as you in the Arms of your Country Magistrate: were I to chuse, I'de have a Generall Lover, one that Courts all, Doats little, and Enjoys every where.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: They are so common, Sister.

sp.speaker: Eme.
sp.p: Not as Country Squires: Alas there's a great difference in the men I speak of, One shall pretend he loves you monstrously, and behind your back cry dam you. A Second court you with Letters, protest he doats upon you, and had rather gaze upon your Eyes, then any she in the whole World beside; and yet the next minute run to a Bawdihouse. A Third comes with that taking Toy call'd Matrimony or Honourable Love, when his whole designe is but to Enjoy you, spend your Portion, and then leave you a Miserable Woman.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: You are well vers'd in the distinctions of Men, Sister.

sp.speaker: Eme.
sp.p: But above all, were I to chuse, give me Sir Generall Amorous, his Business is writ here, here in his Face; and they are much deceiv'd who think he comes to marry 'em.

div.stage: Enter Sir Arthur Twilight and Bramble.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Are all invited?

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: Yes Sir, all you gave order are.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: And will they come?

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: Doubtless, Sir, they are most there already: here's a Note of their Names.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Let me see it, let me see it,— [Reads. Sir Iohn Twiford? what have I to doe with him? I want no Madmen Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: He will not come I'll warrant you, for I told him unless he could produce a new suite of Cloaths, and leave those greasy ones behind him, he could not enter here.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: That's pretty well, it is indeed, i'fack I like the Jeast: Come Daughters let us go in, my Wife and Guests will stay for me, they will indeed, I long to be amongst 'em, for I shall be so merry, so Jocost and pleasant, come dear Girles.

div.stage: Scene draws and discovers seated as at a Banquet, Sir Generall Amorous, Eudoria, Contentious Surly, Petulant Easy, and Sir Geoffry Jolt.
Enter Sir Arthur Twilight, Emelia, Flora, and Bramble, all rise.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Nay, nay sit down, sit down my Worthy Friends, I'fack I joy to see you, why this was kindly done to visit me upon so small a Warning.

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: You see we love you Sir.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: I hope you do so all, I should be loth to have the hate of any man, I'fack I should, come Gentlemen be merry, let's sing, and dance, and drink, and be jocost, ha?

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Still the Old man by Iupiter, come here's a Health, 'tis but a frolick, to the most Superannuated Cuckold in Europe.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Let it go round I'fack.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Fy Sir, there's a Health? I blush to hear it.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: But you shall not: what, blush for a trifle? a Cuckold is a Christian, and so we are all I hope: Mr. Surly you are sullen, dogged, moody, alamort I'fack, come here's a Health to the Lord Mayor of London, ha, that was well thought upon ha, was it not, ha?

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: You are the same man still, you are indeed Sir Arthur, I love a man that has no sense of his own Miseries: look, look, my Landlord's dogged, at that name Cuckold, down in the mouth by Iove, but you bear up briskly still ha, let me embrace thee dear Rogue.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Look Sir Geoffry, mind that Girle, that little Wag Flora, would she not make a brisk she Magistrate ha, would she not ha?

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Yes Sir, yes, a delicate Magistrate.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: You shall see her Dance Sir Geoffry, believe me she has Excellent Parts, come Flora, I'fack she shall be yours all over.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Excellent Girle i'fack, take her Sir Geoffry, take her, I say she shall be yours, i'fack she shall.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: The little Rogue has Charm'd me, she has won my heart again, come little Wag, what say you to a Country Magistrate now ha,—nay nay—I have forgot all the Abuses, all the Affronts you and your Sister put upon me, I have upon my Honour.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: You are too hasty Sir Geoffry, you have my Fathers Consent I must confess, but mine is yet to get; and if you have me you must expect to be made a—

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Cuckold every day, I know it very well, 'tis Hereditary to the Family, but I'll venture that: come little Rogue.

div.stage: Enter Twiford drest Ridiculously, with Stockins of two severall Colours, Breeches altogether out of Fashion, and a Coat quite different from all; and over this a Carpet cut so, that his Head and Arms may come through, and the rest hang like a Senators Gown.

sp.speaker: Twif.
sp.p: —Save you,—save you Ladies, and you my Honourable Lords and very good Cousins, you see I keep my word, but upon my Honour it was something hard to put my self thus into the Fashion, I was at least with a score Lords and Ladies, all very considerable People, who were very considerably pleas'd with my new Play, and truely I believe, it may do very honourably well, but my Lord [To Bramble,] You are a man of Wit, and I know understand in a very Extraordinary manner, I'll show you my Comedy; in the mean time pray Coz oblige me with a Bottle of Wine, and a considerable quantity of Meat; for mark you Coz I am a Wit, and a very hungry Wit, and between you and I those are the best sort of Wits.

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: A Hungry Wit? I believe you: here Sir Iohn, here is what Sir Arthur's Table affords.

div.stage: Gives Twiford Meat, and Wine, both sit down and Eat and Drink very greedily.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Will he not yield yet, will he not be friends ha? The Devil is in the man I think.—

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: He yet Sir is strangely averse to it, but I doubt not at another meeting to compleat the Work, and make you both friends again: and that's a very hard task, but for your sake I'll venture it.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Dear Love, Night is a coming and then,—I say no more, get Sir Generall to your Chamber, work him, work him to a height of Good nature, and then bring me the happy tydings, the joyfull news.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Where shall I find you Sir?

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: In my Study, in my Study Dear, I will make an excuse to the Company for my absence, and expect your Answer. Gentlemen, pardon me for leaving you so soon, a little business unthought of before our meeting, just now came into my Head, and wants to be dispatch'd; be merry, drink and be merry, I'll wait upon you presently.

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: You know your time Sir.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Now will I steal into Eudorias's Chamber, and obscure my self that I may hear how my Wife works him; She has a notable Tongue, and can wheedle a man Delicately, she has indeed.

sp.speaker: Twif.
sp.p: This is Delicate Food my Lord, have you any more?

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: Truly Sir Iohn no. Alas we live here amongst Canniballs, within a short time after Dinner they will devour one another.

sp.speaker: Twif.
sp.p: Truly your Cousins at York are very Considerably well, and every thing is in a very decent Order, and they are all Extreamly brave and Gallant; why look you Cousin, I am going to get a Commission, I have already a Scarf, Sword and Belt, and such Appurtenances; indeed they are the same I had at the Campain at Black-heath, but still they are very Genteele and Modish.—

div.stage: All this while Sir Geoffry Entertains Flora in Dumb show.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: What say you now little Rogue ha?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: I say I shall be the same I ever was, the same jeasting, jearing, designing Woman.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: I must must not be Curb'd.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: You shall not.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Nor be hindred of my Pleasure.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: You shall not.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Nor be lock'd up in my Chamber.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Neither.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Then give me your Hand—I'm Yours.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: Not as you was before, to Couzen me, I hope.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: The Minister shall confute you: but we shall stay too long from the Company.

div.stage: They go into the Scene and sit down, the Scene closes.

sp.speaker: Twif.
sp.p: My Lord you are very obliging, and Madam Flora is very considerably in a good posture, as affairs stand now, and truly by the next month, at the opening of the Campain, she will be much bigger, and fit for a Considerable command.

sp.speaker: Bramb.
sp.p: Shall we not have your Company, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Twif.
sp.p: Cousin, I will wait upon you, and be, my Lord, your most considerably Obliging Faithfull servant to command.

div.head: SCENE Eudoria's Chamber.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Now I shall be made the happiest Citizen in London, I shall indeed; let me see, where shall I hide my self to overhear 'em, I'fack under that Table, it is a Delicate privacy, and very fit for the purpose.

div.stage: Enter Sir Generall Amorous and Eudoria.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Now Joy comes on apace, and every minute produces new Delights. We love without controle, and tread those paths are pointed out by your late Jealous Husband, and what before we studied for with care, is by Sir Arthur flung into our Arms.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Ha! what means this?

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Nothing's more sweet than oft repeated Bliss, especially to one whose Appetite has been so often dull'd by the Embracings of Old Age and Folly.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Ha! is this the Effects? they are reconcil'd, i'faith they are.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Poor Senceless man! that has the impudence to think a Woman can be mew'd up alone, or feed upon a Sapless Tree: by Heaven a Nunnery is Paradise to such a Ladies Chamber.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: I can endure no longer, and yet I dare not stir.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Now we are all desires, and reap each minute a World of New-born Pleasures, whilst in that sordid thing a Feeble Husband, we feed upon a wish, and only live by the imaginary parts of Bliss, Phantasms and Idle Dreams.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: O Devil, Devil, Devil, I shall be made a Cuckold, I find I shall, and dare not offer to prevent it neither.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Let us be reall Lovers, and meet our Flames with vigour, I'm talk'd into an Exstasy,—and shall expire by gazing on your Charms.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: We talk away that time which should be spent in Pleasure.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: A Whore, a Whore, by Heaven a common whore, and I an Arrand Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: I've been too tardy my Eudoria, and will be so no more.
sp.l: Shoot down ye Gods, all, all your Plagues above,
When I neglect the Critick hour of Love.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Confusion! a Pimp, a Pimp, a Pimp.

div.stage: [Falls into a fit of Coughing, they start.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Ha! from whence that Noise?

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Under the Table I think.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: What Slave durst interrupt us?

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: We are betray'd I fear. [Looks under the Table. My Husband! I am lost for ever.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Ha! your Husband? then Impudence assist me. [Draws. Come forth thou scorn of Mankind, and take your Death with patience; look on your Fate, and with a Brow serene, smile whilst I send thy Soul into another World: come out I say.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Not I by Iove, if you will kill me do it in private, for I shall never indure to see it done.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Then—

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Nay sweet Sir Generall hold, 'tis plague enough to be a Cuckold, but I'll forget I am one, if you'll save my Life; Alas, I am not prepar'd to dye.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: So much the greater my Revenge.—

div.stage: [Offers to kill him again, Eudoria hindring him.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Nay let me beg his Pardon Sir, alas the fault was mine, I ought to suffer, shed not the Bloud of such a harmless man, but if you must be cruell, sheath here your Sword, and let my Life and shame end both together.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Come out I say.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Not till you give me Life, I'faith I am sorry, very sorry I interrupted you, I am indeed.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Come out, and I'll consider on't. [Comes from under the Table and kneels.] How durst ye, thou base Jealous Dotard, presume to think an evill thought of us, much more disturb our Pleasures, skulk in our known Recesses, and all to make you mad, horn mad? but to prevent your Lunacy thus I'll—

div.stage: Offers to kill him again, Eudoria Kneels and seems to Weep.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Hold, on my Knees I beg you to forbear, look on his Age, his Innocence and Goodness, look how submissively he bends for Pardon, and also look upon Eudoria's Tears: can they not win you yet, not bate your Fury? then on his Neck I'll hang and perish there, perish and Dye with my dear Loving Husband.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Can you, can you strike now? can you kill Sir Arthur? your best Friend Sir Arthur? can you for all these Tears? for all the Tears of such a loving Wife?—

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Rise, she has gain'd your Pardon: but on Condition that you never talk, nay not so much as think of what has happened, if you doe—

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: Never, alas I will take it for a Dream, a meer Dream, and when I am awake, put it out of my Memory.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Forgive Eudoria then, and with a Zeal as hasty, as you went to Church together.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: I do, I'fack I do, with all my Heart I doe.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Consider Sir, 'tis but a Veniall sin, and not so great as it is Common; for but few Women inviolably observe the Faith they owe their Husbands.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: I'm of your mind Sir Generall, I'fack I am, this 'tis to be Old and fearfull; but 'tis no matter, I'm not the first Cuckold, that's my comfort.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.p: Now all my hopes are lost, quite lost for ever, and I must still be bound to one I hate.

sp.speaker: Twif.
sp.p:
Why, look you Cousins, every thing is Considerably well, and the Affair has been managed with a great deal of Prudence, and my Cousin Geoffry and his Wife Emelia, are mighty jocost and pleasant; and every thing is in an extraordinary Good manner and Posture, and the way is mighty obliging I assure you, they did me the honour to employ me in this great Affair, which is to advertise you that all my good Lords and Ladies are in very Good health, and are—
Enter Sir Geoffry, Emelia, Contentious Surly, Petulant Easy, Flora, Spywell and Bramble. Why look you Cousins, here are all my very good Lords and Ladies, and pray pardon me my Lords, if I leave your Companies so soon, for my very Honourable Friend and Cousin, my Lord—has sent for me, and I am to win a hundred Guinnies to night, which is very considerable, my very good Lords, Ladies and Cousins, Adieu.

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: What, Alamort Sir Arthur? Come, come be merry and sing, I have got your Daughter, I'fack Boy.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: 'Tis Well, 'tis very well, she is a smart Rogue, and will make a good Wife I'll warrant her.—She is my Daughter, and I hope will make you a Cuckold too; that I may have a Son in law of the Family of the Wittalls.—

div.stage: All this time Sir Generall Entertains Flora in Dumb show.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Sir Arthur Twilight all anger being past and quite forgotten, to bind my self for ever to you, and by a Bond that knits Intire Affections, with your Consent and to secure your peace, here will I plant my Love.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: With all my Heart, I care not what you doe, Marry whom you please, I can be but a Cuckold still.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: What say's Emelia?

sp.speaker: Emel.
sp.p: I would say nothing Sir to Matrimony, if you men were not so deceitfull, and yet methinks I long to know what 'tis.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: O 'tis a Pleasing Pain, a Heav'nly Bliss.—

sp.speaker: Emel.
sp.p: Nay, tell me not on't before hand, I hate to have my Pleasures pal'd by talking of 'em, give me your hand, for once I'll venture Marriage, but believe me, if it prove contrary to my Expectation, I'll run for't, go to Law for alimony, and be Mistress to an Alderman.

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.p: He shall be a Cuckold too, I'll perswade my Daughter to be a Whore, and so be reveng'd on him.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: Still he is False, and in the highest nature; I'll study for Revenge now I have lost him, and ruin both together.

sp.speaker: Surly.
sp.p: Sir Generall Amorous, I beg your Pardon for those foul suspicions I had of you and Easy, and hereafter I'll strive to show my Love.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: My thanks shall not be wanting, nor my Rewards, to Spywell and to Bramble, both which have play'd the Parts of Faithfull Servants.
sp.l: Licentious Youth, taught by unruly Fires,
Each moment leads us to Vnjust Desires.
The Ioy once past, and the great Blessing ta'ne;
We grieve to think it cannot come again.
But here that Bliss we do in safety meet,
And lay our Glories at the Victors Feet.
Where uncontroul'd we in our Chains enjoy
Those Pleasures which our Freedom would destroy.

div.head: EPILOGUE, Spoken by Sir ARTHVR.
div.l: THE fate of Writing is like Wedlock dark,
The Wife's Debauch'd by every Modish Spark.
And though a Man Monopolizeth Wit,
He's sure to have but little share of it.
We City Cullies buy our Wive's so Dear
And with such Pains indulge each Wantons Ear
Till they break out, and you Debauch 'em here.
There's scarce a Gallant but has fresh supplies
Of Love and Glances, from her Wanton Eyes.
The fate of Citt and Poet then are even,
For sure both Fools and Cuckolds go to Heaven:
How happy then's the Authour of this Play,
Who although Young's as great a Fool as they?
He swore he did not Write to show his Sence
But his Vnequal'd stock of Impudence.
For though you Raile and Dam, he laughs to see
You more mistaken in his Play then he.
